Polysemy: 'his head / hair / scalp'.

Polysemy: 'his chest / heart / lungs'. Secondary synonym: ə=yay 'his heart, soul' (used mostly in idioms like əyay ʔəxa 'is glad, happy', lit. 'his heart is good') [Couro & Hutcheson 1973: 18].
Glossed as 'his horn (of an animal)'.

Glossed as 'kills one (or one by one)'. Plural: a=č=uː=muč, a=čə=muč, a=čə=muːč. Distinct from aː=wat (pl. a=čə=waːt) 'kills several simultaneously, kills off' [Couro & Hutcheson 1973: 9].

Segments: m ə x ə t̪ u n̪
Comment: Glossed as 'his knee'. Related to ʂə=xə=pə=u-p 'kneels, is kneeling' [Couro & Hutcheson 1973: 42] and saɬʸ=xəu 'his elbow' (ə=saɬʸ 'hand / arm') [Couro & Hutcheson 1973: 41]. Historically mə= in mə=xəu is the word for 'foot / leg'; xəməu is the result of metathesis.

Segments: x ə m ə t̪ u n̪
Comment: Glossed as 'his knee'. Related to ʂə=xə=pə=u-p 'kneels, is kneeling' [Couro & Hutcheson 1973: 42] and saɬʸ=xəu 'his elbow' (ə=saɬʸ 'hand / arm') [Couro & Hutcheson 1973: 41]. Historically mə= in mə=xəu is the word for 'foot / leg'; xəməu is the result of metathesis.
Glossed as 'knows'. Plural: ə==uː=uɹ-p. Secondary synonym: uː=yaːw (pl. u=čə=yuːw-p) 'knows' (used more in southern dialect) [Couro & Hutcheson 1973: 51].
Polysemy: 'a flat or smooth surface (sheet, shell of acorn, bark, husk, leaf) / not plentiful'. No other word for 'leaf' is listed in [Couro & Hutcheson 1973].
Glossed as 'lies, is located'. Cf. wə=lʸak (pl. pə=lʸak) 'lies down' [Couro & Hutcheson 1973: 54].

Comment: Glossed as 'his liver'.
Glossed as 'is long'. Connected by rules of sound-symbolism to ʔə=kuɹ 'is distant, far / long (time)' [Couro & Hutcheson 1973: 3].
Glossed as 'his head louse'. Distinct from xəɬʸčəpuk 'body louse' [Couro & Hutcheson 1973: 21].
Polysemy: 'man / male'. Plural: ʔiː=kʷiː-č. Secondary synonym: ʔiː=pa-č 'man, fellow' (considered slang in Mesa Grande speech, standard word for 'man' in Campo dialect) [ibid.].
Glossed as 'are many, a lot'.

Related to čuː=xiː (pl. čuː=xiː-č-p) 'names, calls by his name' [Couro & Hutcheson 1973: 16]. Cf. ʂiː=muɬ 'clan, group of people who have same last name, term of address for any member of such group; family name' [Couro & Hutcheson 1973: 43].

Glossed as 'its seed'. Secondary synonym: səmiː 'seed' (borrowed from Spanish semilla) [Couro & Hutcheson 1973: 41].

Glossed as 'sits'. Plural: pə=ak. Secondary synonym: ə=waː (pl. nʸə=way) 'is located, sitting, situated, is there (can be said only of a person, animal, or chunky object)' [Couro & Hutcheson 1973: 18].
Polysemy: 'his skin / his hide / is raw / is hung over'. Secondary synonym: kʷeːr 'skin / hide' (borrowed from Spanish cuero) [Couro & Hutcheson 1973: 29].
Glossed as 'sleeps'. Plural: pə=xəma-č.

Segments: ʔ ə s t̪ i k
Comment: Glossed as 'is small, little'. Suppletive plural: ʔəlʸəmis.
Related to the verb uː=xuy 'smokes (of a fire)' [Couro & Hutcheson 1973: 50].

Segments: p ə x ə kʷ iː
Comment: Polysemy: 'stands / stops'. Plural: pə=č=x=uː=kʷiː-p. Distinct from xəaː (pl. pə=č=xəa) 'stands up, rises (from sitting position)' [Couro & Hutcheson 1973: 22].
Polysemy: 'stands / stops'. Plural: pə=č=x=uː=kʷiː-p. Distinct from xəaː (pl. pə=č=xəa) 'stands up, rises (from sitting position)' [Couro & Hutcheson 1973: 22].

Segments: kʷ ə n̪ m ə s aː p
Comment: Glossed as 'star(s)'. Nominalization of the form əməsap 'all night, until dawn' [Couro & Hutcheson 1973: 34], connected by rules of sound-symbolism to the verb əməʂap (pl. əməʂaːp) 'is white, light-colored, gray' [ibid.].
Glossed as 'rock'.
Polysemy: 'day / sun / daytime / time'.
Glossed as 'swims'. Plural: a=čə=puːɬ.
Glossed as 'his tail'.

Polysemy: 'that / that one / him / her / it'. Secondary synonym: nʸip 'that (right close) that you can see' [Couro & Hutcheson 1973: 36]. The basic opposition in the Mesa Grande demonstrative system is between pəyaː (pl. pəya-p) 'this' and puː (pl. pu-p) 'that'. According to [Langdon 1970: 146], "[a] third demonstrative nʸip 'that (other) one' is used much less frequently, does not have a plural form, and its use in Mesa Grande dialect may well be a case of dialect mixture, as it seems to be of much more frequent occurrence in adjoining dialects.".
Glossed as 'this (one)'.
Glossed as 'you'.

Segments: ə n̪ ə p a ɬ
Comment: Glossed as 'his tongue'.
Glossed as 'his tooth, teeth'.
Polysemy: 'wood / stick / tree'.
Glossed as 'are two'.
Glossed as 'goes'. Plural: =aː. Distinct from w=amp (pl. əw=amp) 'walks' [ibid.].
Glossed as 'is hot'. Distinct from piə=piː 'is lukewarm, tepid' [Couro & Hutcheson 1973: 40].

Segments: ʔ ə nʲ aː w a p ʧ
Comment: Object form: ʔənʸaːwap.

Segments: n̪ ə m ə ʂ a p
Comment: Polysemy: 'is white / light-colored / gray'. Plural: ə=mə=ʂaːp.
Polysemy: 'who? / someone'.
Polysemy: 'woman / female'. Plural: siːnʸ.
Glossed as 'is yellow'.
Polysemy: 'is distant / far / long (time)'.
Glossed as 'is heavy'. Plural: wə=iːx ~ wə=aːx.
Glossed as 'is heavy'. Plural: wə=iːx ~ wə=aːx.

Segments: x ə lʲ ə p a j
Comment: Glossed as 'is near'.

Segments: m ə p u t k
Comment: Glossed as 'is short'. Plural: mə=puːt-k.

ID: MesaGrande'Iipay_THIN (OF SHAPE OF OBJECT)_THIN (OF SHAPE OF OBJECT)_Yuman_4
Segments: w ə kʷ iː ɹ p
Comment: Glossed as 'is thin'.
Polysemy: 'wind / is windy / wind is blowing'. Another derivate from this root is ku=yaːy-p 'the wind' [Couro & Hutcheson 1973: 28].
Polysemy: 'worm / caterpillar / maggot'.
Borrowed from Spanish año.

Segments: b u l ˈa fʼ k a ʔ
Comment: Glossed as 'all, everyone'. Word class: animate adjective. Cf. the following textual examples: 'All the people gathered at the house of the host of the fiesta' [ibid.], 'If there are lots of men drinking mescal, in a little while they will all be staggering' [Turner & Turner 1971: 92], 'The mayordomo fed all the men' [Turner & Turner 1971: 150], 'We all have two surnames, (from) our father and also (from) our mother' [Turner & Turner 1971: 172]. According to [Waterhouse 1969: 232], bul-ˈafʼ-kaʔ is derived from the verb =bul-afʼ- 'to pick up and carry in arms' "with the idea of all-embracing". Other synonyms (see below on dialect distribution) include: hˈaway 'all' (example: 'We all went to the ranch'; in the dialects of Ecatepec and San Lorenzo this word means 'daily') [Turner & Turner 1971: 171], howkʼalˈemma 'all, everyone' (example: 'All these men went to their village') [Turner & Turner 1971: 172], hˈoyya 'all, everyone' [Turner & Turner 1971: 172], ɬˈiɬi 'complete, all entire, completely, entirely' [Turner & Turner 1971: 226]. Cf. also ʔa=hˈafʼ-ga 'all, everything' (derived from di=hˈafʼ-ʔma 'to come to an end, to be completely finished, to be used up') [Turner & Turner 1971: 6], ʔentˈero 'all; entire' (a Spanish loanword; "[s]ame usage as Spanish") [Turner & Turner 1971: 128]. According to a dialect survey of Highland Chontal [Turner 1973: 102], 'all' is bulˈafʼkaʔ in San Pedro Sosolotepec, San Miguel, Candelaria, Santa Lucía, San Matías, San José, and Zapotitlán, ɬˈiɬi in San Andrés, Santo Domingo, San Lucas, and Ecatepec, hˈaway in San Juan Acaltepec and San Lorenzo, hˈoyya in San Pablo. We choose bulˈafʼkaʔ as the main synonym, since our main source [Turner & Turner 1971] is based on the San Matías dialect.
Polysemy: 'powder / ashes / dust'. Word class: noun (III/IVb). Variant: ɬ=ˈabiʔ. Plural: ɬ=ˈabi.

Segments: l ˈi ʃ m i kʼ e k
Comment: Glossed as 'tree bark'. Literally 'tree skin', from l=ˈišmi 'skin (of animals) / skin (of fruit) / hide / leather' [Turner & Turner 1971: 197] and ʔal=ʔek 'tree' [Turner & Turner 1971: 19-20], q.v. The meaning 'tree bark' can also be expressed as l=i=b=ˈišmi kʼ=ˈek [Turner & Turner 1971: 47, 146] (l=a=b=ˈišmi 'skin (of a person)').

Segments: l a ɡ ˈu ʔ u
Comment: Glossed as 'stomach / abdomen' ('estómago / abdomen / barriga' in Spanish). Word class: noun (IIa). Plural: ɬ=a=guʔˈu.

Segments: ʔ a ɡ w ˈe ɡ a ʔ
Comment: Glossed as 'large / great' ('grande / abundante / mucho' in Spanish). Word class: animate adjective. Suppletive plural: lan=cˈilaʔ. Secondary synonym: ʔˈuhši 'strong / thick / big' [Turner & Turner 1971: 242].
Polysemy: 'animal / bird / bug'. Word class: noun (IVb). Plural: l=agˈa-ɬwiʔ.

Segments: d i ɡ ˈa ʔ m a
Comment: Word class: transitive verb (I).
Word class: adjective.
Word class: noun (IIa). Plural: ɬ=a=ʍˈacʼ.
Polysemy: 'bone / horn (of an animal)'. Word class: noun (IIIa). Plural: ɬ=egˈal-aʔ ~ ɬ=ˈegaɬ.

Segments: ɬ o n ʃ ˈa h m a ʔ
Comment: Polysemy: 'heart / chest'. Word class: noun (III/IVb). Plural: ɬ=onša-wˈay-hma. Possessed form (3 sg. possessor): ɬ=unšˈa-hmaʔ. Derived from the verb d=unšˈa-ʔma 'breathe' [Turner & Turner 1971: 122] with the instrumental suffix -hmaʔ. Distinct from l=adˈuwe 'las tetas / nipples (of the breast)' [Turner & Turner 1971: 177], glossed as 'woman's breasts' in the list of body parts [Turner & Turner 1971: 356].

Segments: d i b i ʔ ˈe ʔ m a
Comment: Word class: transitive verb (I). Derived from di=bˈi-ʔma 'burn (intr.)' with the transitivizing suffix -ʔe-.

Segments: ɬ a ʔ n ˈa ɬ u k
Comment: Polysemy: 'nail (finger or toe) / claw'. Word class: noun (IIb). Plural: l=a=ʔnaɬˈukʼ.

Segments: l u m m ˈa w a j
Comment: Word class: noun (IIIa). Plural: ɬ=ummˈa-way. A nominalization of the verb d=umma-wˈay-ʔma 'to put', itself derived from d=ummˈa-ʔma 'to move (of a shapleless article, such as clothing) / to carry (clothing)' with the suffix -way- 'down' [Turner & Turner 1971: 117-118]. Secondary synonym: ɬ=edˈumi 'cumulus cloud / the rain god' [Turner & Turner 1971: 222].

Segments: ʔ a ʃ ˈi d a
Comment: Word class: adjective. Distinct from ʔidinˈuwaʔ 'cool, brisk' [Turner & Turner 1971: 167].

Segments: d i ɡ w ˈa j w o
Comment: Glossed as 'arrive (here)'. Word class: intransitive verb (I). The dictionary also lists di=gway-nˈa-wo 'come' [ibid.] with the finalitive suffix -na- that "expresses some measure of permanency or completeness" [Turner 1966: 55]. The stem that contains this suffix and the stem without it are both indiscriminately translated in textual examples as 'come' or 'arrive'.

Segments: d i m ˈa ʔ m a
Comment: Polysemy: 'die / faint'. Word class: semi-transitive verb (I). Durative form: ʔˈaɬ=ma.

Segments: ɡ a l ʦ ˈi k i
Comment: Word class: noun (Ia). Plural: lan=cˈi[ɬ]ki.

Segments: d i ʃ n ˈa ʔ m a
Comment: Word class: transitive verb (I).
Word class: adjective. Plural: ʔihˈul-ay. Cf. di=huɬ-ʔma 'to dry out' [Turner & Turner 1971: 87].

Segments: l ˈa ʃ ʔ m a s
Comment: Glossed as 'ear (of man or animal)'. Word class: noun (IIa). Plural: ɬ=a=šʔmˈacʼ ~ l=a=šʔmacʼ-ˈiʔ. Possessed form (3 sg. possessor): l=ˈi=šʔmas [Turner & Turner 1971: 207].
Polysemy: 'land / earth / year'. Word class: noun (IVb). Plural: ɬ=amˈacʼ. Possessed form (3 sg. possessor): ɬ=ˈemacʼ [Turner & Turner 1971: 153].

Segments: d i d ˈe ʔ m a
Comment: Word class: transitive verb (I).

Segments: ɬ a b ˈi ʔ e
Comment: Polysemy: 'egg / testicles / cocoon (of insects)'. Word class: noun (IVb). Plural: l=abi[ɬ]ʔˈe-ʔ.
Word class: noun (IIa). Plural: l=a=ʔˈu-ʔ. Possessed form (3 sg. possessor): l=ˈi=ʔu [Turner & Turner 1971: 74].

Segments: ʔ a l m a n t ˈe k a
Comment: Polysemy: 'grease / fat'. Word class: noun (Ib). Plural: gal=mantˈeka. Secondary synonyms: l=i=fˈumaʔ ~ l=i=fˈumba 'fat', derived from the verb di=fˈum-ʔma 'to get fat', itself from di=fˈu-ʔma 'to swell up' [Turner & Turner 1971: 73]; gal=kʼˈaʼa 'pine tree sap' ("in Ecatepec and San Lucas this word means manteca; fat") [Turner & Turner 1971: 135]. According to a dialect survey of Highland Chontal [Turner 1973: 102] 'fat' is ʔal=mantˈeka in most villages (Santo Domingo, San Lorenzo, San Pedro Tepacaltepec, San Pablo, San Pedro Sosolotepec, San Miguel, Candelaria, Santa Lucía, San Matías, San José), but ʔel=kʼˈaʼa in Ecatepec. We choose ʔal=mantˈeka as the main synonym, since our main source [Turner & Turner 1971] is based on the San Matías dialect.

Polysemy: 'wing / feather / fin'. Word class: noun (IIIa). Plural: ɬ=a=šˈaʼ ~ ɬ=a=šˈal-aʔ. Possessed form (3 sg. possessor): l=i=šˈaɬ. Another candidate is l=a=bˈimi 'body hair / feather / pen' [Turner & Turner 1971: 174]. The meaning of the latter word is glossed in Spanish only as 'pelo de cuerpo'.

Polysemy: 'fire / a type of insect'. Glossed in Spanish as 'la lumbre, el fuego; un tipo de insecto, el abejorro (coleóptero)'. Word class: noun (IIIb). Plural: l=uŋˈa-y ~ ɬ=uŋˈa-y. Possessed form (3 sg. possessor): ɬ=ib=ˈuŋa [Turner & Turner 1971: 114].
Word class: noun (IVb). Plural: l=adˈu-ye. Secondary synonym: ɬinnˈeha gahˈaʔ 'fish' [Turner & Turner 1971: 228], literally 'water animal'.

Segments: d i j ˈu ʔ m a
Comment: Polysemy: 'jump / leap / fly'. Word class: intransitive verb (II). Durative form: g=ˈiyu.

Segments: l ˈa ʔ m i s
Comment: Polysemy: 'foot / leg' ("this is a general term for leg, a specific term for foot"). Word class: noun (IIa). Plural: l=a=ʔmic-ˈiʔ. Possessed form (3 sg. possessor): l=ˈi=ʔmis [Turner & Turner 1971: 183].
Word class: adjective. Another candidates are ʔimˈanna 'full' [Turner & Turner 1971: 169] and ʔišwˈayda 'full, it's enough / complete' [Turner & Turner 1971: 171].

Segments: d e b ˈi ʔ i ʔ m a
Comment: Polysemy: 'give / divide' ('dar / distribuír / entregar / partir / regalar' in Spanish). Word class: ditransitive verb (IV). Textual examples confirm that this is the main word for 'give'. Secondary synonyms: di=gˈu-ʔma 'give / rent, lease' [Turner & Turner 1971: 76], di=nˈi-ʔi-ʔma 'give (a long, thin object)' (derived from di=nˈi-ʔma 'carry (a long, slender, thin object)') [Turner & Turner 1971: 94-95], di=buʼ-ˈi-ʔma 'give (something large or round)' (derived from di=bˈul-ʔma 'grasp (a large or round object) with hands') [Turner & Turner 1971: 65], d=ummˈa-ʔi-ʔma 'give (a shapeless object, such as clothing)' (derived from d=ummˈa-ʔma 'move (of a shapeless article, such as clothing), carry (clothing)') [Turner & Turner 1971: 117-118, 270]. The ditransitivizing suffix -ʔi-, seen in the last three verbs, is also present in d=ebˈi-ʔi-ʔma, although here the deriving stem was lost.

Polysemy: 'good / delicious'. Word class: adjective. Secondary synonyms: ʔa=čˈulo 'pretty / nice / happy / good' [Turner & Turner 1971: 3] (from Spansh chulo 'pretty / nice'), ʔa=bwˈeno 'good' (from Spanish bueno 'good') [Turner & Turner 1971: 2], ʔa=mehˈor 'good / well' (from Spanish mejor 'better') [Turner & Turner 1971: 37].

Segments: ʔ a ʃ w ˈa j ɡ a
Comment: Word class: adjective. Secondary synonym: ʔˈuškwa 'green' [Turner & Turner 1971: 203]. Distinct from ʔikʼˈašwi 'verde (como fruta no madura); inmatura; crudo, -a / green, unripe' [Turner & Turner 1971: 166].
Polysemy: 'head / hair'. Word class: noun (IIb). Plural: l=a=ʍˈakʼ. Possessed form (3 sg. possessor): ɬ=ˈi=ʍak.

Segments: l a m ˈa n e
Comment: Polysemy: 'hand / arm'. Word class: noun (IIa). Plural: l=a=manˈe-ʔ. Possessed form (3 sg. possessor): l=i=mˈane.
Polysemy: 'head / hair'. Word class: noun (IIb). Plural: l=a=ʍˈakʼ. Possessed form (3 sg. possessor): ɬ=ˈi=ʍak.

Segments: d i ɡ j ˈe h ʔ m a
Comment: Glossed as 'understand, hear with understanding' (but as 'oír; entender; comprender' in Spanish). Word class: transitive verb (I). Durative form: ga=gyˈeg-a. Despite the misleading English gloss, this verb is undoubtedly the main word for 'to hear'. Cf. the following examples: 'When a man sleeps and you see or hear (dogyehʔma) him speaking or groaning, he is dreaming' [Turner & Turner 1971: 81], 'If a man hears (digyehlaʔ) people laughing a little ways away, he too will laugh a little bit; he will smile' [Turner & Turner 1971: 96], 'If he sings softly, no one will hear (nogyehya) his song' [Turner & Turner 1971: 119], 'Now and then you hear (dogyehʔma) the spotted owl hooting at night' [Turner & Turner 1971: 142].

Segments: ɬ o n ʃ ˈa h m a ʔ
Comment: Polysemy: 'heart / chest'. Word class: noun (III/IVb). Plural: ɬ=onša-wˈay-hma. Possessed form (3 sg. possessor): ɬ=unšˈa-hmaʔ. Derived from the verb d=unšˈa-ʔma 'breathe' [Turner & Turner 1971: 122] with the instrumental suffix -hmaʔ.
Polysemy: 'bone / horn (of an animal)'. Word class: noun (IIIa). Plural: ɬ=egˈal-aʔ ~ ɬ=ˈegaɬ.
Word class: personal pronoun.

Segments: d i m ˈa ʔ a ʔ m a
Comment: Glossed as 'kill, assassinate'. Derived from di=mˈa-ʔma 'die / faint' with the transitivizing suffix -ʔa-.

Segments: ɬ e ŋ ˈo n e
Comment: Word class: noun (IVb). Plural: l=eŋo[ɬ]nˈe-ʔ.

Segments: ʔ i ʃ ˈi n a ʔ
Comment: Word class: stative verb (I). The same verbal root as in 'see' q.v.

Segments: l i b ˈe l a
Comment: Word class: noun (IIIa). Plural: ɬ=ib=ˈela. The root without the prefix =ib= is preserved in lˈela-gˈoli 'pine needle' (lˈoli 'pine tree') [Turner & Turner 1971: 189] and lelˈa-ʔmaɬ 'maguey leaf' (ʔˈal=ʔmaɬ 'maguey plant') [Turner & Turner 1971: 20].

Segments: ɡ u n ˈo w j a
Comment: This durative verb is found in the dictionary in the entry for d=una-wˈay-ʔma 'lie down; stretch out (in bed)'. Cf. the following textual example: 'If a man is sitting or lying down (d=unˈow-ya), he can rise and stand up on his feet' [Turner & Turner 1971: 51].
Polysemy: 'liver / center of being'. Word class: noun (IVb). Plural: ɬ=ˈaːda. Possessed form (3 sg. possessor): ɬ=ˈeda.

Segments: ʔ i d ˈo ɡ i
Comment: Polysemy: 'long / tall'. Word class: adjective. Cf. di=dˈoh-ʔma 'to grow' [Turner & Turner 1971: 71-72].

Segments: ɬ ˈa j ɡ w i
Comment: Glossed as 'black louse', i.e. head louse. Word class: noun (IVb). Plural: l=aygwˈi-naʔ ~ l=ˈaygwi-ʔ. Cf. ɬ=ˈayštaɬ 'white louse', i.e. body louse [Turner & Turner 1971: 221-222].

Segments: ɡ ˈa l ʃ a n s
Comment: Glossed as 'man, male'. Word class: noun (Ia). Plural: lan=šanˈukʼ 'people'. This is evidently the main word both for 'man (male)' and for 'man (person)'. Cf. the diagnostic contexts for both meanings: 'Men (lan=šanˈukʼ) make wooden spoons with which women dip out broth' [Turner & Turner 1971: 28] and 'People (lan=šanˈukʼ) are able to eat because they have jawbones' [Turner & Turner 1971: 35]. Cf. lˈ=i=šans 'form / apprearance / color' [Turner & Turner 1971: 197].

Segments: ɡ a l ʃ ˈa n s
Comment: Glossed as 'man, male'. Word class: noun (Ia). Plural: lan=šanˈukʼ 'people'. This is evidently the main word both for 'man (male)' and for 'man (person)'. Cf. the diagnostic contexts for both meanings: 'Men (lan=šanˈukʼ) make wooden spoons with which women dip out broth' [Turner & Turner 1971: 28] and 'People (lan=šanˈukʼ) are able to eat because they have jawbones' [Turner & Turner 1971: 35]. Cf. lˈ=i=šans 'form / apprearance / color' [Turner & Turner 1971: 197].

Segments: ʔ a ʃ p ˈe ʔ
Comment: Glossed as 'many, much'. Word class: adjective. Plural: ʔa=špˈe-laʔ. Cf. di=špˈe-ʔma 'increase, multiply' [Turner & Turner 1971: 104-105].

Word class: noun (IIIa). Plural: ɬ=išˈikʼ. Possessed form (3 sg. possessor): l=ib=išikʼ [Turner & Turner 1971: 132]. Secondary synonym: ɬ=ˈa=biʼ 'skin (man's) / flesh / pulp' [Turner & Turner 1971: 205].

Segments: ɡ a l m ˈu t͡ɬʼ a
Comment: Polysemy: 'moon / month / goddess'. Word class: noun (Ia). Plural: laŋ=muʼˈa.

Segments: ɬ i ʍ ˈa l a
Comment: Polysemy: 'mountain / hill (Spanish 'cerro') / pile'. Word class: noun (III/IIb). Plural: l=iʍalˈa-y ~ l=iʍalˈe-y. Distinct from ɬ=emˈala 'hill (Spanish 'loma') / slope' [Turner & Turner 1971: 223].
Word class: noun (IIa). Plural: ɬ=ˈa=go. Possessed form (3 sg. possessor): lˈ=i=go.

Segments: l a f t ˈi n e
Comment: Word class: noun (IIIa/IVa). Plural: ɬ=a=ftˈine. Possessed form (3 sg. possessor): l=ib=uftˈine.
Polysemy: 'throat / neck'. Word class: noun (IVb). Plural: ɬ=ahˈokʼ-laʔ. Possessed form (3 sg. possessor): ɬ=ˈehokʼ [Turner & Turner 1971: 131].
Word class: adjective.

Segments: l i b ˈu ɡ i ʔ
Comment: Polysemy: 'night / darkness'. Word class: noun (II/IIIa). Plural: ɬ=ibˈu[ɬ]giʔ. Secondary synonym: l=i=mˈuf-kʼoʔ (variant: gˈal=muf) 'darkness / night' [Turner & Turner 1971: 195].

Segments: ɬ ˈa ʔ n a ɬ
Comment: Word class: noun (IIb). Plural: l=a=ʔnal-ˈiʔ ~ l=ˈa=ʔnaʼ ~ ɬ=ˈa=ʔnaʼ. Possessed form (3 sg. possessor): ɬ=ˈi=ʔnaɬ [Turner & Turner 1971: 98].
Negative verbal prefix.

Segments: ʔ a n ˈu l i
Comment: Word class: adjective.

Segments: ɡ ˈa l ʃ a n s
Comment: Glossed as 'man, male'. Word class: noun (Ia). Plural: lan=šanˈukʼ 'people'. This is evidently the main word both for 'man (male)' and for 'man (person)'. Cf. the diagnostic contexts for both meanings: 'Men (lan=šanˈukʼ) make wooden spoons with which women dip out broth' [Turner & Turner 1971: 28] and 'People (lan=šanˈukʼ) are able to eat because they have jawbones' [Turner & Turner 1971: 35]. Cf. lˈ=i=šans 'form / apprearance / color' [Turner & Turner 1971: 197].

Segments: ɡ a l ʃ ˈa n s
Comment: Glossed as 'man, male'. Word class: noun (Ia). Plural: lan=šanˈukʼ 'people'. This is evidently the main word both for 'man (male)' and for 'man (person)'. Cf. the diagnostic contexts for both meanings: 'Men (lan=šanˈukʼ) make wooden spoons with which women dip out broth' [Turner & Turner 1971: 28] and 'People (lan=šanˈukʼ) are able to eat because they have jawbones' [Turner & Turner 1971: 35]. Cf. lˈ=i=šans 'form / apprearance / color' [Turner & Turner 1971: 197].
Word class: noun (IVb). Plural: ɬ=ˈa=gwi. Cf. the verb di=gwˈi-ʔma 'to rain' [Turner & Turner 1971: 78].

Segments: ʔ u n ʃ a l ˈi
Comment: Word class: adjective. Cf. l=unšˈaliʔ 'red heart of a pine tree / fermenting mash (of maguey)' [Turner & Turner 1971: 202].
Polysemy: 'road / ray'. Word class: noun (IIIa). Plural: ɬ=anˈe-yaʔ. Possessed form (2 sg. possessor): l=ob=ˈene [Turner & Turner 1971: 117].
Polysemy: 'vine / root / runner'. Word class: noun (IIIa). Plural: ɬ=ˈime.

Segments: ʔ a ʃ p e j j ˈu ɡ i
Comment: Word class: adjective. The word is related to l=a=špˈeywi 'flat basket' [Turner & Turner 1971: 185]. The Spanish-Chontal index also lists two other candidates under Spanish 'redondo': ʔa=pelotˈeʔ and ʔa=redˈonde [Turner & Turner 1971: 305] (both of them are Spanish loanwords). Textual examples are too few to establish the basic synonym.

Segments: ɬ i b ˈi m a ʦʼ
Comment: Glossed as 'sand (river or ocean)'. Word class: noun (IIIb). Plural: ɬ=ibˈi=macʼ. Derived from ɬ=ˈamacʼ 'land / earth / year' q.v. Distinct from gal=gwˈiša 'limestone sand' [Turner & Turner 1971: 142].

Segments: d i m ˈi ʔ m a
Comment: Word class: transitive verb (I). Durative form: gˈa=mi. Secondary synonym: di=gwˈa-ʔma 'talk / say / think' [Turner & Turner 1971: 78]. Analysis of contexts in [NT 2009] shows that the verb =mˈi- is the main means of introducing direct speech.

Segments: d i ʃ ˈi m ʔ m a
Comment: Polysemy: 'see / find / know'. Word class: transitive verb (I). Labial -m- in di=šˈim-ʔma is a result of assimilation, cf. the durative form ga=šˈin-a.

Segments: ɡ a l f a n ˈu ʔ
Comment: Word class: noun (Ia). Plural: laŋ=fanˈuʔ. Apparently derived from di=fˈa-ʔma 'to sow (seed)' [Turner & Turner 1971: 72]. Secondary synonym: gal=semˈiya 'seed' [Turner & Turner 1971: 155] (a Spanish borrowing).

Segments: d i ɡ u ʦ ˈu j a
Comment: The verb, however, is found in numerous places in the Highland Chontal translation of the New Testament [NT 2009] and in one textual illustration in [Turner & Turner 1971]. Some of the relevant examples: 'And as he sat (migucuya) upon the mount of Olives...' [Matthew 24:3], 'For whether is greater, he that sitteth (ɬogucuya) at meat, or he that serveth?' [Luke 22:27], 'If any thing be revealed to another that sitteth by (nogucuya), let the first hold his peace' [1 Corinthians 14:30], '...where Christ sitteth (digucuya) on the right hand of God' [Colossians 3:1], 'And I saw a great white throne, and him that sat (ɬogucuya) on it' [Revelation 20:11], 'If a man sits (digucuya) all day, his feet will go to sleep' [Turner & Turner 1971: 123].
Source: There is no entry for the durative verb 'to sit, to be sitting' in [Turner & Turner 1971]

Comment: Polysemy: 'skin (man's) / flesh / pulp'. Word class: noun (IIb). Secondary synonym: l=a=b=ˈišmi 'skin (of a person)' [Turner & Turner 1971: 174], derived from l=ˈišmi 'skin (of animals) / skin (of fruit) / hide / leather' [Turner & Turner 1971: 197].

Segments: d i ʃ m ˈa j ʔ m a
Comment: Word class: intransitive verb (I). Durative form: dˈi=šmay.

Segments: ʔ a ɡ ˈa ʔ w a
Comment: Polysemy: 'little / tiny / short / narrow'. Word class: adjective. Suppletive plural: ʔa=cˈogayʔ. Abbreviated form: ʔˈa=ʔwa [Turner & Turner 1971: 6]. Secondary synonyms: duːgˈiniʔ 'small' [Turner & Turner 1971: 114], ʔa=ʔwˈinuʔ 'little' [Turner & Turner 1971: 6], ʔa=hgidˈu 'little (used only to describe animals)' [Turner & Turner 1971: 6].

Segments: l i ɡ u ʃ ˈi s
Comment: Word class: noun (IIIa).

Segments: d e ɡ ˈa ʃ u
Comment: The durative form 'stand, be standing' is found in the Highland Chontal translation of the New Testament [NT 2009]. Here are some examples: 'And Jesus stood (degašu) before the governor...' [Matthew 27:11], 'And it came to pass, that, as the people pressed upon him to hear the word of God, he stood (degašu) by the lake of Gennesaret' [Luke 5:1], 'And now I stand (gagašu) and am judged for the hope of the promise made of God, unto our fathers' [Acts 26:6].
Source: The dictionary [Turner & Turner 1971] gives only the inchoative verb d=egˈaš-ʔma 'stand up' [Turner & Turner 1971: 51]

Segments: ɡ a l ʃ ˈa m n a
Comment: Polysemy: 'star / small river shrimp'. Word class: noun (Ia). Plural: laŋ=šˈamna.
Word class: noun (IVb). Plural: l=abˈikʼ. Possessed form (3 sg. possessor): ɬ=ebˈik.

Segments: ɡ a l ʔ ˈo r a
Comment: Polysemy: 'sun / hour / time / god'. Word class: noun (Ia). Borrowed from Spanish hora 'hour'. Secondary synonym: gal=fˈownaɬ 'a type of hornet / god-like person / sun (obsolete)' [Turner & Turner 1971: 138].

Segments: d i ɡ a f ɡ ˈa j ʔ m a
Comment: Glossed as 'swim (on top of the water)'. Word class: transitive verb (I). Durative form: ga=gˈaf-gay. The verb contains the derivational suffix -gay- 'on top of' [Turner 1966: 269]. Secondary synonyms: demˈuʔma gaʍˈak 'to swim (head under water)', lit. 'to cover head' [Turner & Turner 1971: 55], difʼagˈayʔma lˈahaʔ 'to swim', lit. 'to go down, sink down into water' [Turner & Turner 1971: 75], diʍakʼˈoʔma ʔadˈentro lˈahaʔ 'to swim', lit. 'to pass through the middle of the water' [Turner & Turner 1971: 82], diʍˈafʼʔma 'to walk on top of / to swim' [Turner & Turner 1971: 82].
Word class: noun (IIa). Plural: ɬ=a=bˈo. Possessed form (3 sg. possessor): l=ˈi=bo.

Segments: h i k ˈu ʔ w a
Comment: Glossed as 'that one (there)'. Word class: animate demonstrative pronoun. Variants: hi=kˈuwaʔ ~ kˈuwaʔ ~ kˈuʔwaʔ. Plural: hiɬ=nˈuʔwa ~ hiɬ=nˈuwaʔ ~ nˈuwaʔ ~ hiɬ=nuʔwˈa-ni. The system of demonstrative pronouns in Highland Chontal includes three grades of deixis, a distinction between animate and inanimate demonstratives, and suppletive roots for animate plural forms. Animate demonstratives include: hi=kˈiya 'this (proximal)' (plural hi=nˈiya), hi=kˈaʔa 'this (distal)' (plural hi=nˈaʔa) [Turner & Turner 1971: 171], hi=kˈuʔwa 'that (distal)' (plural hiɬ=nˈuʔwa). Inanimate demonstratives are hi=tˈaʔa 'this (proximal)' and hi=ɬˈiya 'this' [Turner & Turner 1971: 171].

Segments: h i k ˈi j a
Comment: Glossed as 'this one (near by) / he / she / it'. Word class: animate demonstrative pronoun. Variant: kˈiya. Plural: hi=nˈiya ~ nˈiya. See notes on 'that'.
Word class: personal pronoun.
Word class: noun (IIIb). Plural: ɬ=a=bˈaʼ. Possessed form (3 sg. possessor): ɬ=i=baɬ.
Word class: noun (IIa). Plural: l=a=ʔˈay-ʔ. Possessed form (3 sg. possessor): l=ˈi=ʔay.

Segments: ʔ ˈa l ʔ e k
Comment: Polysemy: 'tree / wood'. Word class: noun (Ib). Plural: laŋ=ʔˈekʼ.
Glossed as 'two (inanimate)'. Word class: inanimate adjective (IIIa). Cf. ʔogˈe-šiʔ 'two (animate)'.

Segments: d i ʔ w ˈa ʔ m a
Comment: Polysemy: 'go / walk'. Word class: intransitive verb (I). Durative form: gˈa=ʔwa. Suppletive stems: -łe- (1st and 2nd person plural), -ye- (3rd person plural) [Turner & Turner 1971: 112]. Another candidate is di=cˈe-ʔma 'go / need, take (Spanish 'necesitar')' [Turner & Turner 1971: 108]. Both verbs can occur in similar contexts, cf. 'When a man goes (diʔwˈaʔma) to Oaxaca, he will cross over the river' [Turner & Turner 1971: 77] and 'It's been one or two months since I went (laycewˈoʔma) to Oaxaca' [Turner & Turner 1971: 152]. In the closely related Lowland Chontal, the verb ceː- means 'go and return' [O'Connor 2007: 77]. The following contexts suggest that the meaning of Highland Chontal =ce- may actually be the same: 'I went (aycewˈoʔma) to his house (but) the door was closed; no one is there' [Turner & Turner 1971: 170], 'Yesterday I went (aycˈema) to the mountain...' [Turner & Turner 1971: 209], 'Last year I went (aycewˈoʔma) to Oaxaca three times' [Turner & Turner 1971: 240]. There are other contexts, however, that do not fit so well the meaning 'go and return' (e.g. 'Where did my dog go (gicˈeba)?' [Turner & Turner 1971: 40]), so the matter needs further investigation.

Glossed as 'hot'. Cf. various words for 'warm': ʔa=fˈuŋ-gaʔ 'warm (like a coat or blanket)' [Turner & Turner 1971: 4-5], ʔa=hˈoy-gaʔ 'warm, as a house is warm' [Turner & Turner 1971: 6-7], ʔifunuŋˈeʔ 'warm (liquid)' [Turner & Turner 1971: 167].
Word class: noun (IIa). Plural: ɬ=a=hˈa-y.

Segments: ʔ i j ˈa ŋ kʼ
Comment: Word class: personal pronoun.
Word class: interrogative pronoun.

Segments: ʔ a f ˈu h ɡ a
Comment: Word class: adjective.

Variants: nay ~ ne ~ nˈeci. Plural: nˈayciɬ. Although in [Turner & Turner 1971: 239] nˈayci is described as a relative pronoun, it also serves as an interrogative pronoun, as in the following examples from the Highland Chontal translation of the New Testament [NT 2009]: '...said unto them, Whom (nayci) seek ye?' [John 18:4], 'Jesus saith unto her, Woman, why weepest thou? whom (nayci) seekest thou?' [John 20:15].

Segments: ɬ a ɡ ˈa ʔ n o
Comment: Polysemy: 'woman / female'. Word class: noun (IVb). Plural: l=aga[ɬ]no-ʔ ~ l=aga[ɬ]ʔno-ʔ.

Segments: ʔ u n d ˈa ʔ e
Comment: Word class: adjective. Another synonym with the same root is ʔa=daʔˈaŋ̥ŋ-ga 'yellow' [Turner & Turner 1971: 3]. Cf. also ʔa=boʔˈo 'gold-colored' [Turner & Turner 1971: 2], ʔa=šˈale 'color de arena; tan' [Turner & Turner 1971: 38].

Segments: ʔ a ɡ u l ˈi ʔ
Comment: Word class: adverb.

Segments: ʔ a ɡ ˈu n d a ʔ
Comment: Glossed as 'heavy (in weight)'. Word class: adjective.

Segments: ʔ a s ˈe r k a
Comment: Word class: adverb. A Spanish loanword. Cf. ʔa=weŋ̥ŋ-ga 'near, next to' [Turner & Turner 1971: 39-40].
Word class: noun (IVb).

Segments: ʔ a d ˈe m ɬ k a
Comment: Glossed as 'short (applies to anything)'. Word class: adjective. Another candidate is ʔa=gˈaʔwa 'little / tiny / short / narrow' [Turner & Turner 1971: 5]. The choice between the two synonyms is rather arbitrary, since there are only two textual examples in the dictionary: 'This man is short (ʔadˈemɬka); he never grew...' [Turner & Turner 1971: 3], 'This lasso is very short (g=a=gˈaʔwa)' [Turner & Turner 1971: 23].

Segments: ɬ a j n ˈo f a ɬ
Comment: Word class: noun (IIIb). Plural: l=aynofˈaʼ.

ID: HighlandChontal_THIN (OF HAIR AND THREAD)_THIN (OF HAIR AND THREAD)_Tequistlatecan_1
Segments: ʔ a ʃ a l ˈo f
Comment: Glossed as 'thin (for example, a tortilla or silk material)'. Word class: adjective. Can also be applied to boards [ibid.] or skulls [Turner & Turner 1971: 173].

ID: HighlandChontal_THIN (OF LEAF AND CLOTH)_THIN (OF LEAF AND CLOTH)_Tequistlatecan_2
Comment: Glossed as 'thin'. Word class: adjective. Can be applied to sticks [Turner & Turner 1971: 24], throats of snakes [Turner & Turner 1971: 146].
Polysemy: 'wind / air / north'. Word class: noun (IIIb). Plural: ɬ=ˈawaʔ. Possessed form (3 sg. possessor): ɬ=ib=ˈewaʔ '(his) breath'.

Segments: ɬ a b ˈi m i
Comment: Word class: noun (IVb). Plural: l=abimˈi. Possessed form (3 sg. possessor): ɬ=ebˈimi [Turner & Turner 1971: 111]. This is a general designation, applicable to all kinds of worms. Cf. ɬ=aŋnˈuʔni 'large earthworm (Lumbricus terrestris)' [Turner & Turner 1971: 216] and ɬ=abˈimi g=aŋnˈuʔni 'id.' [Turner & Turner 1971: 205].
Polysemy: 'land / earth / year'. Word class: noun (IVb). Plural: ɬ=amˈacʼ. Possessed form (3 sg. possessor): ɬ=ˈemacʼ [Turner & Turner 1971: 153].

Segments: kʰ ˈu m i tʼʲ i n
Comment: Glossed as 'all (of it)'. Also attested as kˈumičiʔn 'all (of them)' (Sapir/MZ) [ibid.]; kumič-in 'all' (Dixon; Kroeber/F) [Dixon 1910: 363, 374]; kumičin 'all' [Jany 2009: 60].

Segments: m ˈa ʦʼ χ i p a
Comment: Sapir's note: "phonetics not certain". Also attested as mˈaʈipa 'ashes, dirt' (Sapir/MZ) [ibid.]; maʈipxa ~ maʈipa 'ashes' [Dixon 1910: 363, 374].

Segments: h ˈi p χ a ʧʼ i
Comment: Glossed as 'bark (not "skin")'. Also attested as h=ˈipʰaʈiʔ 'bark of tree' (Sapir/MZ) [ibid.]; h=ipxaǯi 'skin, bark' [Dixon 1910: 363, 376].

Segments: h ˈi pː χ a ʧ i
Comment: Glossed as 'bark (not "skin")'. Also attested as h=ˈipʰaʈiʔ 'bark of tree' (Sapir/MZ) [ibid.]; h=ipxaǯi 'skin, bark' [Dixon 1910: 363, 376].

Segments: h ˈu tʲ u n e w
Comment: Also attested as h=ˈučuʔn-ew (Sapir/MZ) [ibid.]; h=uʈun-eu [Dixon 1910: 364, 378], h=učen-eu (Kroeber/F) [Dixon 1910: 364, 378].
Also attested as čˈeːwo (Sapir/S) [ibid.]; ʈewu 'be big / big' [Jany 2009: 33, 56, 157].

Segments: t ˈi ʔ i r a
Comment: Polysemy: 'small game (birds, squirrels) / birds'. Also attested as tˈiʔla 'birds' (Sapir/MZ) [ibid.]; diʔla 'bird' (Kroeber/F) [Dixon 1910: 364, 376]; tiʔla [Jany 2009: 25, 164], tiʔra [Jany 2009: 50].
Absent from [Berman 2001] and [Dixon 1910]. Attested in the following sentence from Harrington's materials: "I am afraid of the dog, he might bite, I am afraid".

Segments: ʧʰ ˈe l e ʔ i
Comment: Sapir's note: "tc῾ clear; not tʸ-type". Also attested as čele-ʔˈi (Sapir/MZ) [ibid.]; čeleː-i [Dixon 1910: 364, 377]. Cf. čʰˈeliʔ 'brown' [Berman 2001: 1057] - the same word?
Also attested as šiʈqi 'blood' [Dixon 1910: 364, 376]. Cf. šˈiʈaʔ (Sapir/MZ) [Berman 2001: 1056], səʈi 'blood' [Dixon 1910: 364, 376] - the same root with different suffixation?

Segments: ʦʰʲ ˈa tʰ χ u n
Comment: Also attested as ča=txan- [Jany 2009: 79]. Cf. h=ˈuʔʈun 'bone' (Sapir/MZ) [Berman 2001: 1056]; h=utxun 'bone' [Dixon 1910: 364, 377]. Comparison with these forms suggests that cʰʸˈa= in cʰʸˈa=tʰun is a prefix, but its function remains unclear.

Segments: h u ʔ s ˈi ʔ
Comment: Also attested as h=usi (Kroeber/F) [Dixon 1910: 364, 376]. Distinct from sˈiʔra 'breast, "bag that gives milk"' (Sapir/AB); šˈiʔra 'woman's breast' (Sapir/MZ) [Berman 2001: 1057], šiːra ~ šiʔila ~ siːʔleːye 'woman's breast / milk' [Dixon 1910: 364, 376].

Segments: p ˈo l a χ o t
Comment: Polysemy: 'fingernail / claw'. Also attested as bolaxot (Dixon), bulaxut (Kroeber/F) 'fingernail' [Dixon 1910: 365, 375].

Segments: h a w ˈe t a ʔ m
Comment: Also attested as haweːdam (Dixon), awatamaxni (Kroeber/F) 'cloud' [Dixon 1910: 364, 372]. Cf. hˈawitami 'cloudy' (Sapir/AB) [Berman 2001: 1058].

Also attested as ešo- 'cold' [Dixon 1910: 364, 371]; ˈešoh 'cold, be cold' [Jany 2009: 27, 65]. Opposed to ʔeloh 'hot' in the following example: "She drinks the hot (ʔeloh) liquid, she does not eat cold (ʔešoh)" [Jany 2009: 65].

Also attested as =owa-tok- 'to come' [Dixon 1910: 375], =wa-tok-, =wa-k- 'to come' [Dixon 1910: 378], =uwa-tku- [Jany 2009: 35, 43, 74, 117]. -kʰ- and -tku- are directional suffixes with the meaning 'hither' [Jany 2009: 134]. The verb has the same root as 'to go' q.v.
Also attested as qe- 'to die' [Dixon 1910: 365, 373], qʼe- 'to die' [Jany 2009: 18, 23, 33].

Segments: s ˈi ʧʼ e l a
Comment: Also attested as šičʼ-ˈela (Sapir/S), šˈičʼ-ela (Sapir/MZ) [ibid.]; šič-ella ~ sič-ela 'dog' [Dixon 1910: 365, 376]; šinč-ˈela 'dog' [Jany 2009: 23, 27], šič-ela 'dog' [Jany 2009: 58, 81, 163, 192]. Cf. sˈičʼ-iwi 'wolf' (Sapir/AB) [Berman 2001: 1072]. Wintu sečila 'dog' is probably borrowed from Chimariko. H. Pitkin in his "Wintu Dictionary" (p. 532) tentatively derives this word from Wintu se-čilaː 'to tear apart', but the semantic side of this derivation is not convincing, whereas similarity between Chimariko words for 'dog' and 'wolf' suggests that these words are not recent borrowings into Chimariko.
Other attestations: luː- 'to drink' [Dixon 1910: 365, 374]; luʔ- 'to drink' [Jany 2009: 124, 154].

Segments: ˈa ʧ x u n m i
Comment: Also attested as ačxumni 'dry' [Dixon 1910: 365, 371].

Segments: h ˈi s a m a
Comment: Also attested as h=isam 'ear' [Dixon 1910: 365, 376]. Dixon compares this word with =šem- 'to listen' [Dixon 1910: 366, 376].

Polysemy: 'earth / dirt / land'. Also attested as ˈama 'earth / country' (Sapir/MZ) [ibid.]; ama 'country / earth / ground / mountain' (Dixon; Kroeber/DT) [Dixon 1910: 365, 371]; ʔama 'country' [Jany 2009: 18].
Also attested as =ama- ~ =ma- 'to eat' [Dixon 1910: 365, 371]; =ama- 'to eat' [Jany 2009: 33].
Polysemy: 'egg / sugar / anything sweet'. Also attested as anoːqai 'egg' [Dixon 1910: 365, 371].

Sapir notes: "Abe Bush suggested that hύsɔt meant eyes and hύsυ meant eye, but he was a little doubtful" [ibid.]. Also attested as h=ˈusoʔt (Sapir/MZ) [ibid.]; h=usot 'eye' [Dixon 1910: 365, 376]; =usot 'eye' [Jany 2009: 71-72]. Cf. the word for tears, husˈoʔa [Berman 2001: 1069], literally 'eye-water'.

Sapir notes: "Abe Bush suggested that hύsɔt meant eyes and hύsυ meant eye, but he was a little doubtful" [ibid.]. Also attested as h=ˈusoʔt (Sapir/MZ) [ibid.]; h=usot 'eye' [Dixon 1910: 365, 376]; =usot 'eye' [Jany 2009: 71-72]. Cf. the word for tears, husˈoʔa [Berman 2001: 1069], literally 'eye-water'.
Also attested as piːʔa 'fat (n.)' [Dixon 1910: 365, 375].

Polysemy: '(big) coarse feather / tail feather / wing'. Also attested as h=uto ~ h=utu ~ utuː 'feather / wing' [Dixon 1910: 365, 377]. Related to the verb 'fly' q.v. Distinct from h=imi, glossed as 'feather' in [Dixon 1910: 374], but as 'hair (of any kind)' in [Berman 2001: 1062].

Polysemy: '(big) coarse feather / tail feather / wing'. Also attested as h=uto ~ h=utu ~ utuː 'feather / wing' [Dixon 1910: 365, 377]. Related to the verb 'fly' q.v. Distinct from h=imi, glossed as 'feather' in [Dixon 1910: 374], but as 'hair (of any kind)' in [Berman 2001: 1062].

Polysemy: '(big) coarse feather / tail feather / wing'. Also attested as h=uto ~ h=utu ~ utuː 'feather / wing' [Dixon 1910: 365, 377]. Related to the verb 'fly' q.v. Distinct from h=imi, glossed as 'feather' in [Dixon 1910: 374], but as 'hair (of any kind)' in [Berman 2001: 1062].
Also attested as hˈaːpo (Sapir/S) [ibid.]; aːʔpu 'fire' [Dixon 1910: 365, 371]; ˈapu 'fire' [Jany 2009: 27].
Related to 'feather' q.v.

Also attested as h=ˈupʰoʔ 'foot' (Sapir/MZ), h=ˈipʰa 'his foot' (Sapir/S) [ibid.]; h=upo 'foot' [Dixon 1910: 365, 375]; upʰo ~ h=upʰu 'foot' [Jany 2009: 226]. Distinct from h=ˈitan 'leg' [Berman 2001: 1063].

Segments: h i ʦʼʲ ˈo l a m
Comment: Glossed as 'full, it's full'. Also attested as h=ičo-lam 'full' [Dixon 1910: 365, 372]; h=učo-lla 'full' [Jany 2009: 97].
Also attested as =awu- 'to give' [Jany 2009: 33].

Segments: h i s ˈi ʔ tʼ a
Comment: Also attested as hisi-kni (Dixon), hisi-ki (Kroeber/F) 'good' [Dixon 1910: 365, 372]; (h)isiʔ 'good' [Jany 2009: 158].

Segments: h ˈi m a m s u ʔ
Comment: Also attested as himamto 'green' (Dixon), iːmamšu 'blue' (Kroeber/F) [Dixon 1910: 366, 372]. Distinct from ˈomenatʰ 'green, unripe' [Berman 2001: 1070]. See also 'yellow'.
Glossed as 'hair (of any kind)'. Also attested as h=imi 'feather' [Dixon 1910: 365, 374].
Polysemy: 'hand / arm'. Also attested as h=iʈa ~ h=ita (Dixon), h=iča (Kroeber/F) 'hand / finger / arm / shoulder' [Dixon 1910: 366, 377]; =iʈa 'hand' [Jany 2009: 71].
Polysemy: 'hand / arm'. Also attested as h=iʈa ~ h=ita (Dixon), h=iča (Kroeber/F) 'hand / finger / arm / shoulder' [Dixon 1910: 366, 377]; =iʈa 'hand' [Jany 2009: 71].
Also attested as h=ima 'head / hair' [Dixon 1910: 366]; h=imaʔ 'head' [Jany 2009: 22, 75].

Segments: χ ˈu k e j a t
Comment: Polysemy: 'hear / understand'. Form is glossed as 'he can't hear'. = is the negative prefix. Also attested as =keː- 'to hear' [Dixon 1910: 366, 373]; =ikei- ~ =ikeː- 'hear' [Jany 2009: 22, 104, 219].

Segments: h u s a ʔ a n ʧ eː i
Comment: Also attested as husančei (Kroeber/F) [ibid.].
Glossed as 'horns'. Also attested as h=ˈuwisʸ 'horns' (Sapir/MZ) [ibid.]; h=oweš 'antlers / horn' [Dixon 1910: 363, 378]; =uweš- 'horn' (Harrington) [Jany 2009: 72].
Glossed as 'me'. Also attested as noː-ut 1st singular personal pronoun [Dixon 1910: 322], noʔ-ot 1st singular personal pronoun [Jany 2009: 52].
Also attested as =ko- 'to kill' [Dixon 1910: 366, 373]; =akʰo- 'to kill' [Jany 2009: 17, 33].

Segments: h i t x a n i m a x a
Comment: Also attested as h=itxan-emaxa 'knee' (Kroeber/DT) [ibid.]. Derived from h=ˈitan 'leg' [Berman 2001: 1063].

Segments: h ˈi ʦʼ a h u
Comment: Cf. =ˈucʼʸahu-n 'I don't know it' [ibid.]. Also attested as =ʈahu- 'to know' [Dixon 1910: 366, 377].

Segments: h i t a x a i
h a ʧ ˈuː t a t
Comment: Glossed as 'he's lying down'. Also attested as =ču- 'to lie on ground, to lie down / sleep' [Dixon 1910: 358, 366]; =ačuː-da- 'lie down' [Jany 2009: 21].
Also attested as h=ušˈiʔ 'liver' (Sapir/MZ) [ibid.]; h=uši 'liver (?)' [Dixon 1910: 366, 376].
Also attested as h=iču-n 'long' [Dixon 1910: 366, 372]; h=ičʰu 'long' [Jany 2009: 163, 225]. See also 'short'.
Polysemy: 'man / male'. Also attested as ˈiʈiʔ 'man' (Sapir/MZ) [ibid.]; iʈi 'man' [Dixon 1910: 366, 373]; ʔiʈi 'man' [Jany 2009: 132]. Related to =iʈi- 'to grow' [Dixon 1910: 366, 373].
Polysemy: 'man / male'. Also attested as ˈiʈiʔ 'man' (Sapir/MZ) [ibid.]; iʈi 'man' [Dixon 1910: 366, 373]; ʔiʈi 'man' [Jany 2009: 132]. Related to =iʈi- 'to grow' [Dixon 1910: 366, 373].
Glossed as 'plenty, lots'. Also attested as eta (Dixon), hitat (Kroeber/F) 'many / much' [Dixon 1910: 366, 371]; hita ~ hit ~ ita ~ it 'many, lots' [Jany 2009: 24].
Glossed as 'plenty, lots'. Also attested as eta (Dixon), hitat (Kroeber/F) 'many / much' [Dixon 1910: 366, 371]; hita ~ hit ~ ita ~ it 'many, lots' [Jany 2009: 24].

Glossed as 'deer'. Also attested as aːʔa 'deer' [Dixon 1910: 364, 370]  There is no word for 'meat' in [Berman 2001] or [Dixon 1910]. However, two examples in [Jany 2009] show that the word ʔaʔa 'deer' [Jany 2009: 82] can mean 'meat' as well: ʔaʔa-ʔna-tinta 'It isn't meat' [Jany 2009: 38] and hamat, ʔaʔa xamanat, paačʰikut 'She eats, (but) she does not eat meat, not any more' [Jany 2009: 226].
Polysemy: 'moon / sun' (used more for 'moon'). In [Dixon 1910: 369] alla is glossed as 'sun', cf. also asi-n-alla 'sun, day-sun', himi-n-alla 'moon, night-sun' [Dixon 1910: 312].
Polysemy: 'moon / sun' (used more for 'moon'). In [Dixon 1910: 369] alla is glossed as 'sun', cf. also asi-n-alla 'sun, day-sun', himi-n-alla 'moon, night-sun' [Dixon 1910: 312].
Also attested as awu 'mountain' [Dixon 1910: 367, 371]; ʔawu 'mountain' [Jany 2009: 160].
Also attested as h=awa 'mouth' (Dixon; Kroeber/DT) [Dixon 1910: 367, 378].
Also attested as h=iki 'neck' [Dixon 1910: 373]; čʰa=ki 'our throats' [Jany 2009: 52].
Also attested as amani-nhu 'new' [Dixon 1910: 367, 371].

Segments: ˈa m a n i t
Comment: Also attested as amani-nhu 'new' [Dixon 1910: 367, 371].
Also attested as hime (Dixon), hiːmi (Kroeber/DT) 'night' [Dixon 1910: 367, 372]; hime 'night' [Jany 2009: 80].
Also attested as hime (Dixon), hiːmi (Kroeber/DT) 'night' [Dixon 1910: 367, 372]; hime 'night' [Jany 2009: 80].
Also attested as h=oxu 'nose' [Dixon 1910: 367, 379]; h=oxu 'nose' [Jany 2009: 163].

..-na (used only with vowel-initial verb stems), 2) the suffix -kuna/-kʼuna/-ʔna (used with all verb stems and with predicate nominals; the variant -ʔna occurs after vowels), and 3) the particle kuna/kʼuna (used with negative imperatives and in negative predicate nominal clauses). The common element of these morphemes/morpheme complexes is the suffix -na.
Source: According to [Jany 2009: 177], there are three strategies of negating clauses: 1) the verbal circumfix x-

Comment: Also attested as pʼun 'one' (Sapir/S) [ibid.]; pun ~ pʼun 'one' [Dixon 1910: 367, 375]; pʼun 'one' (Harrington/SN; Harrington/LM) [Jany 2009: 57].

Polysemy: 'person / Indian'. Also attested as čʼˈimal 'man' (Sapir/S) [ibid.]; čimar (Dixon), čimal (Dixon; Kroeber/F), ǯimar (Kroeber/DT) 'person / Indian' [Dixon 1910: 367, 377]; čʼimar 'person' [Jany 2009: 23].

Polysemy: 'person / Indian'. Also attested as čʼˈimal 'man' (Sapir/S) [ibid.]; čimar (Dixon), čimal (Dixon; Kroeber/F), ǯimar (Kroeber/DT) 'person / Indian' [Dixon 1910: 367, 377]; čʼimar 'person' [Jany 2009: 23].

Segments: h ˈi t a kʰ t a
Comment: Glossed as 'it's raining (?), rain (?)'. Apparently a verbal form, cf. h=ˈitakʰ-tʼa 'it rains' (Sapir/AB), h=itak-ˈintʼa 'it is raining' (Sapir/AB), h=itˈakʰ-ni 'it rains' (Sapir/S) [ibid.]. Cf. also h=iːtak 'rain' (glossed as noun) [Dixon 1910: 367, 372]. The noun mutˈakwe 'rain' (Marr/MZ) [Jany 2009: 231] is probably derived from the same root, but the derivational pattern is unclear.

Segments: j ˈe ʦ χ o l
Comment: Glossed as 'red (like blood)'. Another possible candidate is wili-ʔiː 'red' [Dixon 1910: 367, 378]; also in the following example: tiʔla himaʔ wiliʔi 'Red woodpecker heads' (Harrington) [Jany 2009: 163]. This word, however, is differently glossed by Sapir: wˈili-ʔi 'bay (like horse)' (Sapir/AB) [Berman 2001: 1056].

Segments: j ˈa ʦ χ o l
Comment: Glossed as 'red (like blood)'. Another possible candidate is wili-ʔiː 'red' [Dixon 1910: 367, 378]; also in the following example: tiʔla himaʔ wiliʔi 'Red woodpecker heads' (Harrington) [Jany 2009: 163]. This word, however, is differently glossed by Sapir: wˈili-ʔi 'bay (like horse)' (Sapir/AB) [Berman 2001: 1056].

Glossed as 'trail'. Also attested as hissa 'trail' [Dixon 1910: 369, 372]. There is no word glossed as 'road' or 'path' in [Berman 2001] and [Dixon 1910]. Cf., however, the locative form hisa-lla 'on the road, in the road' [Jany 2009: 79].
Also attested as aːči 'root' [Dixon 1910: 368, 371].
Also attested as nolle 'round' [Dixon 1910: 368, 375].

Segments: ʔ a m a j ˈa qʰ a
Comment: Also attested as ama-yaːqa 'sand' [Dixon 1910: 368, 371]. The first element of this compound is ˈamːa 'earth', the second can be tentatively identified with aqʰˈa 'water', if -y- results from a kind of sandhi.

Glossed as 'to talk'. Cf. h=ˈikʼo-t ~ h=ˈikʼo-t 'to talk / word' (Sapir/AB) [ibid.]. Also attested as =koː- ~ =goː- 'to talk' [Dixon 1910: 369, 373]; =ikʼo- 'to say' [Jany 2009: 35]. Examples: x=ukʼo-na-n "He didn't say" [Jany 2009: 37]; "Dailey said (h=ikʼo-t): the bull hooked me, I dodged" [Jany 2009: 99]; "What are they saying (čʰa=kʼo-ʈe-teʔw) about us?" [Jany 2009: 173]. Secondary synonym: čʰe- 'say' [Jany 2009: 18]. Example: "He took his hand telling (h=ičʰe-mda) him (to go home)" [Jany 2009: 214]. Apart from the verbs =ikʼo- and čʰe-, Chimariko has the following discourse markers, introducing direct speech: pʰaʔyit 'he/she thus said', si-t 'he/she said', and si-deʔw 'it was said, they said'. Jany notes that "[w]hile these words show some verbal morphology, such as tense, aspectual, and derivational suffixes, they do not have any pronominal markers, and they cannot form clauses by themselves" [Jany 2009: 68].

Segments: h ˈi m a m t a
Comment: Also attested as =mam- 'to see' [Dixon 1910: 368, 374]; =imam- 'see' [Jany 2009: 18]. Dixon compares the word with =mat- 'to find' [Dixon 1910: 374]. Thus, the final -m in =imam- may be segmentable.

Segments: h ˈi w o h i n tʼ a
Comment: Glossed as 'he's sitting there, is at home'. Also attested as =wo- 'sit (singular)' [Dixon 1910: 333, 368]; =iwo- 'sit down / stay' [Jany 2009: 20, 33]. Secondary synonyms: =pat- 'sit (plural)' [Dixon 1910: 333, 368], =epat- 'sit / stay' [Jany 2009: 18, 33]; h=ˈičit-mi-t 'to sit down' (Sapir/AB) [Berman 2001: 1068], =čit- 'to sit' [Dixon 1910: 368].
Also attested as =po- 'to sleep' [Dixon 1910: 368, 375]; po-...-mu 'sleep' [Jany 2009: 23, 158]. Secondary synonym: =ču- 'to lie on ground, to lie down / sleep' [Dixon 1910: 358, 366] (see 'lie').
Also attested as uleːta 'small' [Dixon 1910: 368, 378]; ʔuleyta 'little' [Jany 2009: 25].
Also attested as qeː 'smoke' [Dixon 1910: 368, 373]. The noun 'smoke' is not found in [Berman 2001].

Segments: h oː h ˈa tː a
Comment: Also attested as =hoa- ~ =hɔ- 'to stand' [Dixon 1910: 368, 372].
Also attested as munu 'star' [Dixon 1910: 368, 374].
Glossed as 'rock'. Also attested as qʰˈaːʔa 'rock' (Sapir/S) [ibid.]; qaːʔa 'stone' [Dixon 1910: 369, 373]; qʰaʔa 'rock' [Jany 2009: 85].

Polysemy: 'sun / moon'. Secondary synonym: ˈasi-n-alːa 'sun' [ibid.], (Kroeber/DT) asi-n-alla 'sun' [Dixon 1910: 369, 371], literally 'day luminary', see 'moon'. ˈala ~ alla alone is also attested with the meaning 'sun', but, as Sapir notes, "used more for 'moon'" [Berman 2001: 1064].

Apparently can refer to humans, cf. the forms ixuː 'I swim', nixuːyaxana 'shall you swim?' in [Dixon 1910: 348]. Alternative candidate: =iʔekta- 'swim', attested in the following example: "They swam (h=iʔekta-ʔxa-t) all in the river, they were many" (of crawfish) [Jany 2009: 227]. The same verb (with a different suffix?) is attested in [Berman 2001: 1069]: n=ˈiʔekya-kʰ "you (fish) hurry up and swim hither!" (from Chimariko formula).
Also attested as aquːye 'tail' [Dixon 1910: 369, 371]; ʔaqʰuye 'tail' [Jany 2009: 131, 227].
Cf. pʰˈaʔm-ot 'that one' (Sapir/AB) [ibid.]. Also attested as pam-ut ~ pa-ut ~ p-ɔt 'that' [Dixon 1910: 322]; pʰˈaʔm-ot 'that' [Jany 2009: 55-56].
Glossed as 'this one'. Also attested as qew-ot ~ q-ɔt 'this' [Dixon 1910: 322]; kim-ot 'this' [Jany 2009: 55-56].
Glossed as 'this one'. Also attested as qew-ot ~ q-ɔt 'this' [Dixon 1910: 322]; kim-ot 'this' [Jany 2009: 55-56].
Glossed as 'you'. Also attested as mˈaːm-utʰ 'you' (Sapir/S); mam-ut 2nd singular personal pronoun [Dixon 1910: 322]; mam-ot 2nd singular personal pronoun [Jany 2009: 52].
Also attested as h=ipen 'tongue' [Dixon 1910: 369, 375]. Related to =pen- ~ =hen- 'to lick' [Dixon 1910: 366, 372, 375].
Glossed as 'teeth'. Also attested as h=ucu 'teeth' [Dixon 1910: 369, 378]; h=ucʼu 'tooth' [Jany 2009: 24].
Also attested as aːtʼa (marked by Dixon with a question sign) 'tree' [Dixon 1910: 369, 371]; ʔaʈa- 'tree' [Jany 2009: 78].
Also attested as aːtʼa (marked by Dixon with a question sign) 'tree' [Dixon 1910: 369, 371]; ʔaʈa- 'tree' [Jany 2009: 78].
Also attested as aːtʼa (marked by Dixon with a question sign) 'tree' [Dixon 1910: 369, 371]; ʔaʈa- 'tree' [Jany 2009: 78].
Also attested as xoku ~ qɔquː 'two' [Dixon 1910: 369]; qʰoqʰu (Harrington/SN), xokkʰu (Harrington/LM) 'two' [Jany 2009: 57].

Glossed as 'to go'. Also attested as =wa-m-, =owa- 'to go' [Dixon 1910: 365, 375, 378]; =uwa- 'go' [Jany 2009: 18]. The root =uwa- is used with various directional suffixes: with -k or -tku 'hither' it means 'to come' q.v., with -m 'thither' it means 'to go'. Dixon also lists under 'to go' the following forms: =a-, =waum-, and =wawum-. The two latter forms contain the "retornative" suffix -wu- [Jany 2009: 104] and directional -m 'thither' and are translated in textual examples as 'to go home', cf. n=uwa-wu-m 'go home' (imper.) [Jany 2009: 118]. The root =uwa- may contract with the suffix -wu-, producing =uwo- or =uwu-, cf. y=uwˈo-m-ni "I'm going home" (Sapir/AB) [Berman 2001: 1061], h=uwu-m-naʔči-t "All went home" [Jany 2009: 41], "Today she came (uwa-tku-n), she went back home (h=uwo-m-ni) at once" [Jany 2009: 63], y=uwo-m imiʔna-n "I want to go home" [Jany 2009: 190]. The stem =a- (more precisely =aʔa- ~ haʔa-), also glossed by Dixon as 'to go', occurs in the following examples: h=aʔa-tok-yaʔ-kon "He is going to come back" [Jany 2009: 42] (-tok- - directional 'hither'), h=aʔa-tpi-m-da "(the man) came out" [Jany 2009: 216], haʔa-čʰa-k-inta "(the bull) was taking after me" [Jany 2009: 222], haʔa-čʰa-m-ta "he (the bull) took after me" [Jany 2009: 222], n=ˈaʔa-wu-tpi-m "go out!", n=ˈaʔa-wu-tpi-kʰ "come out!" [Berman 2001: 1061].

Segments: ʔ ˈe l o h tʼ a
Comment: Glossed as 'hot'. Also attested as ʔeːloh-(w)ˈintʼah 'it's hot' (Sapir/S) [ibid.]; elo- (Dixon), elox-ni (Kroeber/F) 'hot' [Dixon 1910: 366, 371]; eloh 'hot / be hot' [Jany 2009: 65]. The word for 'warm' is not attested.
Also attested as ˈaːqʰa (Sapir/S), aːkʰˈa (Sapir/WF) 'water' [ibid.]; aːʔka ~ aːqa 'water' [Dixon 1910: 369, 370]; ʔaqʰa 'water' [Jany 2009: 227].

Segments: n ˈaː ʧʰ i t a s
Comment: Glossed as 'us, we, all of us'. Sapir's note: "doubtful about -tαṛs". Also attested as na-čid-ut 1st plural personal pronoun [Dixon 1910: 322]; na-čʰit-ot 1st plural personal pronoun (contracted form na-čʰ-ot) [Jany 2009: 52].

Glossed as 'what?'. Also attested as paːči 'what' [Dixon 1910: 322]; pačʰaʔ ~ pačʰi 'what' (Harrington) [Jany 2009: 55]. Alternative candidate: qʰˈo-cʰi ~ qʰˈo-si  'what?' (Sapir/AB) [Berman 2001: 1071]; qɔ-či 'what' [Dixon 1910: 322]; qʰo-si-  'what' (Harrington) [Jany 2009: 54].

Glossed as 'what?'. Also attested as paːči 'what' [Dixon 1910: 322]; pačʰaʔ ~ pačʰi 'what' (Harrington) [Jany 2009: 55]. Alternative candidate: qʰˈo-cʰi ~ qʰˈo-si  'what?' (Sapir/AB) [Berman 2001: 1071]; qɔ-či 'what' [Dixon 1910: 322]; qʰo-si-  'what' (Harrington) [Jany 2009: 54].

Segments: m ˈe n e ʔ i
Comment: Glossed as 'white (animal)'. Also attested as mene-ʔi 'white' [Dixon 1910: 369, 374]; meneʔ 'be white' [Jany 2009: 157]. The following example from Harrington's fieldnotes shows that this word is not restricted to animals: ʔawa hičʰekčʰa meneʔe "White house paint" [Jany 2009: 164]. Secondary synonym: mˈatʸa-ʔi ~ mˈača-ʔi 'clear / white' (Sapir/AB), mˈaca-ʔi 'white' (Sapir/MZ) [Berman 2001: 1072]; mata-ʔi 'clean' [Dixon 1910: 364, 374].

Glossed as 'who?'. Also attested as qo-mas 'who' [Dixon 1910: 322]; qʰo-mas 'who' (Harrington) [Jany 2009: 92]. Alternative candidate: awi-lla 'who' [Dixon 1910: 322]; ʔawi-lla 'who' (Harrington) [Jany 2009: 55]. The difference between these two pronouns is unclear. Cf. the following examples from Harrington's fieldnotes: ʔawilla musudaʔ "Who are you?" and qʰomas musudaʔ "Who are you?" [Jany 2009: 174].

Segments: p ˈu n s a r
Comment: Polysemy: 'woman / wife'. Also attested as puncar 'woman / wife' [Dixon 1910: 369, 370, 376]; pʰuncar 'woman' (Harrington) [Jany 2009: 216].

Segments: p ˈu n s aː r
Comment: Polysemy: 'woman / wife'. Also attested as puncar 'woman / wife' [Dixon 1910: 369, 370, 376]; pʰuncar 'woman' (Harrington) [Jany 2009: 216].

Segments: p ˈu n ʦ aː r
Comment: Polysemy: 'woman / wife'. Also attested as puncar 'woman / wife' [Dixon 1910: 369, 370, 376]; pʰuncar 'woman' (Harrington) [Jany 2009: 216].

Segments: h i m i t a
Comment: Also attested as hˈiːmidanda 'it is heavy' [Dixon 1910: 346]. Not attested in [Berman 2001]. Dixon also lists čumidan 'happy (?), heavy (?)' [Dixon 1910: 366, 378].
Also attested as ˈaːkʼi 'salt' (Sapir/S) [ibid.]; aqi 'salt' [Dixon 1910: 368, 371]. Cf. ʔakʼice 'salt place' (place name from Harrington's data) [Jany 2009: 50].

Segments: χ ˈu ʦʰʲ u lː a
Comment: Also attested as xuː=iču-lan 'short' [Dixon 1910: 368, 372, 379]; x=očʰu-lla 'short' [Jany 2009: 65]. Literally 'not long', from =ˈicʰʸu- 'long' q.v. with negative prefix =.

ID: Chimariko_THIN (OF SHAPE OF OBJECT)_THIN (OF SHAPE OF OBJECT)_Chimariko_1
Comment: Another candidate is tqeʔer-in 'thin' [Dixon 1910: 369, 376].

Segments: h ˈi kʼ o s e ʔ
Comment: Also attested as ikos-eːta 'wind' [Dixon 1910: 370, 373]. According to Dixon, derived from =kos- 'to blow' [Dixon 1910: 312].

Segments: h e m u t a
Comment: Cf. ˈawin 'big worm' (Sapir/AB) [Berman 2001: 1072], xawin ~ qawin 'caterpillar' [Dixon 1910: 364, 378].

Segments: ʔ w iː w aː w a h ú ʔ
Comment: Glossed as 'everything'. Also attested as ʔíːwawaw 'all' (CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 7].

Segments: ʔ w iː w a w á w
Comment: Glossed as 'everything'. Also attested as ʔíːwawaw 'all' (CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 7].

Segments: m á h a w a
Comment: Also attested as máhawaː (SS), máawaː (CW) 'dust / ashes' [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 19].

Segments: ʔ í ʧ n i t
Comment: Also attested as ʔícnit 'belly' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 10].

Segments: kʼ i m p í ʔ
Comment: Also attested as kʼ=impíʔ 'large' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 30]. kʼ= is probably a deverbative nominalizing prefix.
Also attested as cʼíːcʼaːx 'bird' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 10].

Segments: t á ʔ u x á w iː k
Comment: Glossed as 'he bit him'. Morphological analysis: t= 3rd person near past reportative prefix; =áʔu= root 'mouth'; =xáw- root (same as in 'to kill', q.v.); -iːk momentaneous aspect suffix. The verb has a suppletive "collective plural", cf. the following examples: kʼw=áʔu=xáw-ik "He bit once" (kʼw= 3rd person near past inferential prefix); kʼw=eːp=xáwʔː-ik "He bit every once in a while" (=eːp= suppletive form of the root 'mouth') [Silver 1966: 112]. Cf. also the forms adduced by Bright: kúxːawiːk 'he bit it' (FW) and káwʔikʼaʔ 'he bit me' (CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 10].

Segments: ʔ eː p x ú t á r a x i ʔ
Comment: Also attested as ʔeːpxuʔ-táraxiʔ 'black' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 10], cf. also ʔeːpxúʔ 'black / dark'  (SS, CW) [ibid.]. -táraxi- is a "perception attributive" suffix meaning 'black' [Silver 1966: 140], also occurring in ma-taraxíʔ 'black paint for face' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 37].
Also attested as ʔáːxta 'blood' [Silver 1964: 171] and ʔáxta 'blood' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 11].
Also attested as ʔáːk 'bone' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 11].

Segments: ʔ í ʧ w a t
Comment: Glossed as 'chest'. Also attested as ʔícwat 'chest (of body)' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 13]. Distinct from ʔimpá 'nipple / woman's breast' [Silver 1961: 5].

Segments: ʔ éː r a x a
Comment: Glossed as 'fingernail'. Also attested as ʔéːraxa 'nail (of finger or toe)' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 34].

Segments: ʔ íː p aː k ú ʔ

Comment: Also attested as ʔisːíkʼ 'cold (adj.)' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 15].

Segments: kʼ úː h u j i kː a
Comment: Glossed as 'he came'. Tentative morphological analysis: kʼ= same as kʼw= 3rd person near past inferential prefix; =úːhuy- root; -ikːa same as -ikʼːa directional suffix 'hither'. Cf. kʼw=éːʔ=ihiːy-ikːa 'they came' [Silver 1961: 13] (nature of the morpheme =éːʔ= is unclear); kʼw=íhiːy-iːkʼaʔ ~ kʼw=íːy-iːkʼaʔ 'he came to visit me' [Silver 1966: 89] (-iːkʼaʔ directional suffix 'hither'); stʼ=uhuːy-ákʼ 'Come again!' [Silver 1966: 232] (stʼ= subjunctive prefix; -akʼ directional suffix 'hither'). =úːhuy- ~ =uhuːy- and =íhiːy- are probably allomorphs of the same root; their distribution is unclear. Cf. also kw=úːy-ikaː '(a man) came here' (FW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 15].

Segments: k w í r i k i k
Comment: Glossed as 'he died'. Tentative morphological analysis: kw= 3rd person near past inferential prefix (expected form of this prefix is kʼw=, but glottalization is often absent in data collected from FW); =írik- root (see below); -ik momentaneous aspect suffix. Cf. the adjective kʼ=iríkʼ 'dead' [Silver 1961: 12; Bright & Olmsted 1959: 17 (SS, CW)] with the same root. Cf. also ʔátʼuːkʼiːk 'he died' (CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 17].
Also attested as ʔáːpsu 'dog' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 18].

Segments: k w í ʦː i k
Comment: Glossed as 'he's drinking'. Morphological analysis: kw= 3rd person present inferential prefix; =ícːi- root 'drink'; -k momentaneous aspect suffix. Also attested as kw=íci-k 'he's drinking' (CW, FW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 18].
Morphological analysis: kʼ= deverbative nominalizing prefix; =icːúr verbal root 'to dry' [Silver 1966: 92].
Also attested as ʔísaːk 'ear' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 19].
Polysemy: 'land / ground / dirt / country'. Also attested as tʼárak 'earth / dirt / ground / land' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 19].

Segments: k w í ʧ k u k
Comment: Glossed as 'he's eating'. Morphological analysis: kw= 3rd person present inferential prefix; =íčku- root 'eat'; -k momentaneous aspect suffix. Also attested as kw=ícku-k 'he's eating' (CW, FW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 19].

Segments: s u m p í tʼ i r i r
Comment: Also attested as sumpítʼiːrir 'egg' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 19].
Also attested as ʔwí 'eye' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 20]. Sh. Silver notes a variation between ʔuyíːta 'eye' (instrumental case) and ʔwíːtaʔ 'id.' [Silver 1966: 79, 93].
Glossed as 'fat / grease'. Also attested as ʔíːnːaʔ 'grease' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 25]. Cf. kʼ=inːúʔ 'fat (adj.)' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 20].
Also attested as ʔápːaʔ 'feather' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 21].
Also attested as ʔimːá 'fire' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 21].

Segments: r úː h u k a ʔ
Comment: Glossed as 'it's flying (crawling)'. Morphological analysis: r= 3rd person present direct evidential prefix; =úːhu- root (singular allomorph; glossed as 'along in space' in [Silver 1966: 110]); -kaʔ 'progressive suffix'. Also attested as r=úːhu-kaːʔ 'it's flying' (CW, FW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 22]. Plural: r=áhaː-kaʔ 'they're flying (crawling)' [Silver 1961: 13]. Morphological analysis: r= 3rd person present direct evidential prefix; =áhaː- root (plural allomorph; glossed as 'along in space (coll.)' in [Silver 1966: 110]); -kaʔ 'progressive suffix'.
Also attested as ʔákʼus 'foot' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 22]. Distinct from ʔárawáy 'leg' [Silver 1961: 5].

Segments: kʼ a h u t í k n a ʔ
Comment: Morphological analysis unclear. Initial kʼ= may be a deverbative nominalizing prefix, present in many other adjectives. W. Bright adduces a completely different form: kúpaknaʔ 'full' (CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 23].

Glossed as 'he gave it to him'. Morphological analysis: t= 3rd person near past reportative prefix; =áwi- root; -ːk momentaneous aspect suffix. Another example of the same verb is kʼw=áw-iːkʼaʔ 'They gave it to me' [Silver 1966: 176, 190], attested in the following sentence: "They are the ones that gave me a boat" (kʼw= 3rd person near past inferential prefix; -iːkʼaʔ "directional transitive" suffix, marking 1st singular and 2nd person object). Also attested as kw=aw-áː 'I give' (SS) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 24] (kw= 1st person singular near past prefix; -aː durative aspect suffix) and kúːwikaː 'he gave it to me' (FW) [ibid.] (apparently the same form as kʼw=áw-iːkʼaʔ above). Another candidate is the verb =iːču-, represented by the following forms: č=íːčuː-t-aːʔ "He gave it to him" [Silver 1966: 73] (č= 3rd person passive prefix; -t- "transitive marker"; -aːʔ momentaneous paucal suffix); kwícuːtiːk 'he gave (something large) away' (CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 24].

Segments: kʼ á r i sː á ʔ
Comment: Also attested as kʼ=arisáʔ 'good' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 24]. kʼ= is a deverbative nominalizing prefix; this is clear from the verbal form k=árisːáʔ "You (sg.) be good!" [Silver 1966: 45], where initial k= is a 2nd person hortative prefix. Cf. the verbal attributive suffix -ríːʔi- 'good, correct' [Silver 1966: 140] and the enclitic particle ríːʔay 'good' (occurs with substantives) [Silver 1966: 226].

Segments: ʔ éː r i ʧ ú m p a x i ʔ
Comment: Also attested as ʔer=icúmpaxiʔ 'grass' (SS) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 25]. Cf. ʔíčumpaxíʔ 'grass' [Silver 1961: 10]; ʔicumpaxíʔ 'grass / green' (CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 25] and the verbal attributive suffix -ičumpaxi 'yellow, green' [Silver 1966: 140]. The nature of the element ʔéːr is unclear.

Also attested as ʔíːnːax 'hair' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 26]. One of the XIXth century records of Shasta (wordlist collected by Edward Ross) has {itt-chik} for 'hair' and {in-nauh} for 'head' [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 26].

Glossed as 'hand / fingers / arm' in [Silver 1966: 209]. Also attested as ʔápka 'hand' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 26]. Distinct from ʔáːčar 'arm' [Silver 1961: 5], ʔáːcar 'arm' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 7].
Also attested as caːráw 'head' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 27]. See also notes on 'hair'.

Segments: k w í k h j a w i k
Comment: Glossed as 'he hears it'. Morphological analysis: kw= 3rd person present inferential prefix; =ikhyaw- root; -ik momentaneous aspect suffix. Also attested as ya=t=ikwaw-áː 'do you hear it?' (FW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 27] (ya= enclitic question marker; t= 3rd person interrogative prefix; -aː durative aspect suffix); t=íkyaw-ik yaː 'did you hear it?' (CW) [ibid.]; r=íkyaw-aːʔ 'he heard it' (FW) [ibid.] (r= 3rd person present direct evidential prefix; -aːʔ momentaneous paucal suffix); kʼw=íkyaw-ik 'he heard it' (CW) [ibid.] (kʼw= 3rd person near past inferential prefix).

Segments: ʔ í w aː s ú r ʔ
Comment: Also attested as ʔiwaːsúrʔ 'heart' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 27].

Also attested as wáːpaʔ 'horn' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 28] and wáʔàpʰàʔ 'horns' (from J. P. Harrington's field notes) [Silver 1980: 249]. The latter form suggests that the first vowel in wáːpaʔ is due to contraction.
Allomorph used with the possessive marker: yapː- ~ yaːpʼ- [ibid.]. Also attested as yáːʔaːʔ 'I' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 28].

Segments: kʼ w í ʧ k a x á w iː k
Comment: Glossed as 'he killed him'. Morphological analysis: kʼw= 3rd person near past inferential prefix; =ička= root; =xáw- root (same as in 'to bite', q.v.); -iːk momentaneous aspect suffix. Also attested as kʼw=ícka=xaw-iːk 'he killed him' (CW, FW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 29]. The first root apparently also occurs in kwíckaːxtik 'he put out the fire' (FW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 39].

Segments: ʔ í ʧʼː i p k a
Comment: Also attested as ʔícʼipka 'knee' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 30].

Segments: t iː w áː j kʼ a h aː ʔ
Comment: Glossed as 'he knew it'. Morphological analysis unclear. t= is the 3rd person near past reportative prefix. The morpheme =iːwáːy- is apparently identical with the root =iːway- 'perceive', mentioned in [Silver 1966: 106]. Also attested as máː t=íːwey-kʼaː 'I don't know' (CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 30] (t= 1st person singular negative prefix); r=iːwéy-kaːʔ 'he knows' (CW, FW) [ibid.] (r= 3rd person present direct evidential prefix; -kaːʔ progressive aspect suffix).
Also attested as xanːár 'leaf' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 30].

Glossed as 'lie (rest): it's lying'. Morphological analysis: r= 3rd person present direct evidential prefix; =ic- root (since Bright does not distinguish between hissing and hushing affricates, this root may in fact contain č); -aːʔ durative aspect suffix. Also attested as kw=íc-aːʔ 'it's been lying for some time' (SS) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 30] (kw= 3rd person present inferential prefix). The form kw=íkʼway-ik 'he's lying' in [Silver 1961: 14] is dubious: it is not clear whether we deal here with the verb 'to lie (recline)' or 'to lie (tell lies)'. Cf. also ráteːkwayaʔ 'he's lying down' (CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 30] and skáraːkaʔ 'You (sg.) are lying down' [Silver 1966: 43]. The choice between these alternative candidates is arbitrary.
Also attested as ʔéːpsiʔ 'liver' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 31].

Segments: ʔ ú kː a x á w h i ʔ
Comment: Polysemy: 'long / tall'. Also attested as ʔukːaxúːhiʔ (SS), ʔukːaxúːiʔ (CW) 'long' [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 31]. The same root is found in ʔukːáx-maː 'far away', lit. 'a-long-way hither' (-maː 'hither') [Silver 1966: 198].

Glossed as 'head louse'. Also attested as ciːták 'louse' (CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 31]. Distinct from ʔíwiːwíʔ 'body louse' [Silver 1961: 9], ʔiwiwíʔ 'grayback louse' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 31].

Segments: ʔ a w a t í k h w aː
Comment: Polysemy: 'man / husband'. Also attested as ʔawatíkwaː 'man / husband' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 32].
Glossed as 'a lot of'. Variant form: akːwará 'a lot of' (CW) [ibid.]. Also attested as ʔukːaríʔ (SS), ʔakːwaráʔ (CW) 'many' [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 32].

Segments: ʔ a r á w ʔ
Comment: Polysemy: 'deer / meat'. Also attested as ʔaráwʔ 'deer (Odocoileus columbianus)' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 17]. The meaning 'meat' is attested only in the following sentence: kwípxik ʔinːáʔ ʔaráwʔ "She roasted the meat" [Silver 1961: 12]. The polysemy 'deer / meat' is commonplace in Californian languages. Secondary synonym: ʔúpsi 'flesh' [Silver 1966: 45].
Polysemy: 'sun / moon'. Also attested as cʼúwar 'sun / moon' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 33, 48].
Also attested as wákːwey 'mountain' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 34].

Also attested as ʔáw 'mouth' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 34]. In nominal and verbal compounds this root has allomorphs -ahu- and -aʔu-: cf. ʔahú=čučːuʔ ~ ʔáw=čučːuʔ 'beard' [Silver 1966: 90], =ahu=sːa- 'to talk' [Silver 1966: 119], =áʔu=xáw- 'to bite' [Silver 1961: 14].

Segments: kʼ eː k w á j i k
Comment: Tentative morphological analysis: kʼ= deverbative nominalizing prefix; =eːkwáy- root (see below); -ik unidentified suffix. Apparently related to the verb 'to name': t=éːkʼway-aːy-ik 'He did the naming' [Silver 1961: 14] (t= 3rd person near past reportative prefix; =éːkʼway- root; -aːy- "transitive marker"; -ik momentaneous aspect suffix). The word is attested in the following sentence: makáy kwačʼːú kʼeːkwáyik kwántuːmeː "I mentioned his name" [Silver 1966: 214]. Also attested in one of the XIXth century Shasta wordlists (recorded by William B. Hazen in 1857) as {ka-kwai-ee} 'name' [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 34]. Another wordlist (recorded by George Crook in 1856) has {kau-shik} 'name' [ibid.], a form we were unable to identify with anything in the more modern data.
Also attested as ʔíkʼuk 'neck' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 35].
Also attested as ʔapxáː 'night' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 35].
Also attested as ʔéːr 'nose' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 36].
Negative particle, occurs both in indicative and prohibitive function. Also attested as máːa 'no' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 36].
Also attested as cʼáːʔaʔ 'one' [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 36]. According to [Silver 1966: 75], the two principal informants used different forms: čʼaːʔa (CW), čʼeːʔa (SS) 'one'.
Polysemy: 'Indian / person'. Also attested as ʔís 'person / Indian' (CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 37].

Segments: ʔ i s t ú kʼ
Comment: Cf. the verbal stem =učːi- 'precipitate as rain does' [Silver 1966: 76]. The forms from the XIXth century Shasta word lists are all different: {o-chee} (William B. Hazen, 1857), {i-dur-ka} (George Crook, 1856), {da -keh} (Stephen Powers, 1872), {útsbik} (Dana, 1841) 'rain' [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 39]. The first of these forms is related to the verb =učːi-, but we were unable to identify the remaining forms with anything in the more modern data.

Segments: ʔ é ʔ e x t i ʔ
Comment: Also attested as ʔéːʔeːxtiʔ 'red' [Silver 1964: 175] and ʔéːxtiʔ 'red' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 40].
Glossed as 'trail'. Also attested as ʔícːaː 'trail / road' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 50].

Segments: ʔ a r áː ʔ i ʔ
Comment: S. Silver's wordlist has wátikʼumːar 'root' [Silver 1961: 10], but W. Bright gives an apparently identical word with a more specialized meaning: mátːikumːar, ʔítːikumːar 'root of Ponderosa pine' (SS) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 41].

Segments: ʔ í kʼ a n kʼ a n

Comment: Also attested as tʼácːu 'sand' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 41].

Segments: kʼ w í sː i k
Comment: Glossed as 'he said'. Morphological analysis: kʼw= 3rd person near past inferential prefix; =ísːi- root; -k momentaneous aspect suffix. Other attested forms: ʔw=isːí-k ~ ʔw=ísːi-k 'he said' [Silver 1966: 86] (ʔw= gerundial prefix); kw=isː-áːʔ 'I said' [Silver 1966: 139] (kw= 1st person singular near past prefix; -aːʔ momentaneous paucal suffix). The root is =isːi- ~ =isːa [Silver 1966: 85, 138].

Segments: k w í mː i k
Comment: Glossed as 'He sees it'. Morphological analysis: kw= 3rd person present inferential prefix; =ímːi- root; -k momentaneous aspect suffix. Other attested forms: r=ímːaʔ 'Let him see it!' [ibid.] (r= 3rd person hortative prefix); sw=ímːi-k 'I see it' [Silver 1964: 175] (sw= 1st person singular present prefix); kw=imː-áːʔ 'I see' (SS) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 42] (kw= 1st person singular near past prefix; -aːʔ durative aspect suffix); kw=ímːi-ːk 'he saw it' (FW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 42]. The root is =imːi- ~ =imːa [Silver 1966: 77]. Another candidate is the verb represented by the following forms: r=éːwaʔ 'he sees it' [Silver 1961: 12; Bright & Olmsted 1959: 42 (CW, FW)] (r= 3rd person present direct evidential prefix); s=éːwaʔ 'I see it' [Silver 1966: 43] (s= 1st person singular present prefix), pʼ=éːwa 'I saw it' [Silver 1966: 45] (pʼ= 1st person singular distant past prefix). The semantic difference between the two verbs is unknown, so the choice is arbitrary.
Glossed as 'seed (pit)'.

Segments: r í sː a w k
Comment: Glossed as 'he's sitting down'. Morphological analysis: r= 3rd person present direct evidential prefix; =isː- root; -aw- unidentified morpheme; -k momentaneous aspect suffix. The verb has a suppletive plural (cf. [Silver 1966: 111]): r=ár-aːk-eʔ 'they're sitting down' [Silver 1961: 13] (r= 3rd person present direct evidential prefix; =ar- root; -aːk- collective suffix; -eʔ collective perfective aspect suffix). Also attested as r=ísː-aːw-k 'he's sitting down / he's at home' (CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 44]; kwisːáykaː 'he sat down' (FW) [ibid.]; kwácʼ kwísːik 'there he sits' (SS) [ibid.]. The root is =isːaː- sg., =aráː- pl. [Silver 1966: 111].
Polysemy: 'skin / peeling'. Also attested as ʔícka 'skin (of person)' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 44].

Segments: r í ʦ m a s aː k a ʔ
Comment: Glossed as 'he's sleeping'. Morphological analysis: r= 3rd person present direct evidential prefix; =icma- root; -s- root; -aːkaʔ progressive aspect suffix. Also attested as kw=ícma-s-aːkaʔ 'He's sleeping' [Silver 1966: 108] (kw= 3rd person present inferential prefix); k=icma-sí 'go to sleep!' (SS) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 45] (k= 2nd person hortative prefix); r=ícma-s-aːkaʔ 'he's sleeping' (CW, FW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 45]. The verb has a suppletive plural: r=íwanː-akaʔ 'they're sleeping' [Silver 1961: 13]; kw=íːwanː-akaʔ 'They are sleeping' [Silver 1966: 108]. The root is =icma-siː- (sg.), =iːwanːi- ~ -iːwanːa (pl.) [Silver 1966: 108, 110].
Glossed as 'little'. Also attested as ʔátʼuk 'small' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 45]. Secondary synonym: ʔániːni 'little' [Silver 1966: 26].
W. Bright does not distinguish between hissing and hushing affricates in Shasta, so the root may actually contain č.

Segments: r á kʼ aː w aː ʔ
Comment: Glossed as 'he's standing'. Morphological analysis: r= 3rd person present direct evidential prefix; =akʼ- root; -aːwaːʔ imperfective aspect suffix. Also attested as r=ákʼ-awaːʔ 'he's standing' (CW, FW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 47]. The verb has a suppletive plural: r=éːrukʼ-awaːʔ 'they're standing' [Silver 1961: 13]. The root is =akʼa- (sg.), =eːrukʼa- (pl.) [Silver 1966: 110].

Segments: x a kː w éː s u r
Comment: Also attested as xakːwéːsur 'star' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 47].
Glossed as 'rock'. Also attested as ʔícːaʔ 'rock' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 40].
Polysemy: 'sun / moon'. Also attested as cʼúwar 'sun / moon' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 33, 48].

Segments: r u m p a k a ʔ
Comment: Glossed as 'he's swimming'. Morphological analysis: r= 3rd person present direct evidential prefix; =ump- root; -akaʔ progressive aspect suffix. Also attested as r=úmp-akaːʔ 'he's swimming' (CW, FW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 48]. The verb has a suppletive plural: y=éːw-eːk-ir-aː 'we are swimming around (dur.)' [Silver 1966: 69] (y= 1st person plural prefix; =eːw- root (plural allomorph); -eːk- collective suffix; -ir- distributive suffix; -aː durative aspect suffix). The root is =umpi- ~ =umpa (sg.), =eːw- (pl.) [Silver 1966: 112]. Secondary synonym: stʼ=íːpu 'You (sg.) are going to bathe' [Silver 1966: 44] (stʼ= subjunctive prefix); k=íːpuʔ 'You (sg.) bathe!' [Silver 1966: 66] (k= 2nd person hortative prefix); kw=ípu-k 'he's swimming' (CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 48] (kw= 3rd person present inferential prefix; -k momentaneous aspect suffix).

Segments: ʔ í h i w a
Comment: Also attested as ʔihíwa (SS), ʔiíwa (CW) 'tail' [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 48].

Shasta has three demonstratives, whose meaning is summarized by Sh. Silver as follows: "<weˑ> specifies relative immediacy, <miˑ> specifies relative remoteness, and <inˑá> specifies, as it were, the absence of immediacy or remoteness" [Silver 1966: 219].
See notes on 'that'.
Allomorph used with the possessive marker: maːm- [ibid.]. Also attested as máyʔiː 'you (sg.)' (CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 55].

Segments: ʔ é h e n a
Comment: Also attested as ʔéhena (SS), ʔéena (CW) 'tongue' [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 50]. Related to the verb =eheni- 'to lick' [Silver 1966: 76; Silver 1980: 249]. Extremely interesting is the form from the Shasta wordlist collected in the mid XIXth century by Edward Ross: {ip-huah} 'tongue' [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 50].
Glossed as 'teeth'. Also attested as ʔícʼaw 'tooth' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 50].

Segments: ʔ á k aː h aː
Comment: Also attested as ʔákʼaːha (SS), ʔákʼaːa (CW) 'tree' [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 50].

Also attested as xúkːaʔ 'two' [Silver 1961: 1; Bright & Olmsted 1959: 51 (SS, CW)]. The variant without glottalization is probably a misrecording: in her later works Sh. Silver cites only xúkʼːa [Silver 1964: 176; Silver 1966: 203].

Segments: kʼ w á tː a ʔ
Comment: Glossed as 'he's gone'. Morphological analysis: kʼw= 3rd person near past inferential prefix; =atːaʔ root. Cf. the following example: kuráː t=atí-ːma 'where are you going?' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 24] (t= 2nd person singular interrogative prefix; -ːma directional suffix 'thither'). The verb has a suppletive plural: kʼw=éʔːaʔ 'they're gone' [Silver 1961: 13]. The root is =atːi- ~ =atːa (sg.), =eʔːi- ~ =eʔːa (pl.) [Silver 1966: 110].

Segments: ʔ áː t i tʼː ú ʔ
Comment: Glossed as 'hot'. Also attested as ʔatitːú (SS, CW), ʔitːú (SS), tutːú (CW) 'hot' [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 28]. Morphological segmentation of these forms is unknown.
Also attested as ʔácːa 'water' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 53].
Allomorph used with the possessive marker: čaːkʼ- [ibid.]. Also attested as cʼaːkáʔ 'we' (CW, FW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 53].

Also attested as kuːcʼá 'what?' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 53]. Dialectal variant: tuːčʼá [Silver 1966: 68]. According to S. Silver, "SS identified the t-variant as indicative of the speech of the Shasta Valley Shasta" [Silver 1966: 5].

Segments: ʔ í tʼ aː j ú
Comment: Also attested as ʔítʼaːyuʔ 'white' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 53]. Related to ʔítʼay 'white earth for face-paint' (SS) [ibid.].
Polysemy: 'who / someone'. Also attested as tákaː 'who?' (CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 53].

Segments: t a r íː ʧʼ i ʔ
Comment: Polysemy: 'woman / wife'. Also attested as tarícʼiʔ 'woman / wife' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 54]. Cf. ʔárapxaː 'woman (used with nationality)' [Silver 1961: 2].

Segments: x a nː á r kʼ éː ʔ eː k i kʼ á r i k
Comment: xanːár is 'leaf', but we cannot at present translate other parts of the phrase. XIXth century wordlists have the following word(s): {e-ho-tik} (recorded by George Crook in 1856), {ik-kwoi-too} (recorded by William B. Hazen in 1857) 'yellow' [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 55].
Also attested as ʔukáx 'far' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 20].

Segments: ʔ i ʧ k á kʼ
Comment: Polysemy: 'heavy / strong'. Also attested as ʔíckakʼ 'tough / strong' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 50].
Also attested as ʔamːáx 'near' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 35].
Also attested as ʔáːtax 'salt' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 41]. Variant form: ʔámtax (identified by SS as belonging to Kʼaːmátʼwaː dialect) [Silver 1966: 93].

Segments: ʔ e h é kʼː u
Comment: Also attested as ʔihíkːu (SS), ʔíːkːu (CW) 'short' [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 43].

Segments: n ú h uː sː u
Comment: Also attested as núhusu (SS), núusu (CW) 'snake / blue racer snake' [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 45].
Also attested as ʔáːska 'wind' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 54]. Related to the verb kw=áːski-k 'wind's blowing' (CW) [ibid.].

Segments: ʔ á m t aː w a
