Comment: Glossed as 'earthworm'. Also attested as ʔámtaːwa 'angleworm' (SS, CW) [Bright & Olmsted 1959: 55]. Another candidate is cʼuːpírʔ 'worm' (SS) [ibid.].

Segments: ʧʼ i k íː s u ʔ

Comment: Morphophonemic shape {□ṭʼiː}.

Segments: ʔ i n o q o ʧ
Comment: Cf. ʔino 'dust' [McLendon 1973: 66].
Cf. ʔahtʰiy 'big (plural)' [Oswalt 1961: 303].
Contains instrumental prefix qa= 'with the teeth' [Oswalt 1961: 146].
Polysemy: 'bone / strong'.

Segments: m u h kʰ u j ʔ
Comment: Glossed as 'to burn up one'. Contains instrumental prefix mu= 'with heat' [Oswalt 1961: 143-144]. Mač- (morphophonemic shape {□mac-}) 'burn', cited by [Oswalt 1964: 424-425] is apparently an intransitive verb.
Glossed as 'finger (or toe) nail' in [Oswalt 1961: 38] and as 'claw' in [Oswalt 1964: 424-425]. Morphophonemic shape {□he°cʼ}.

Segments: ʔ i h j uː m
Comment: Morphophonemic shape {ʔihyu°m-}.
Morphophonemic shape {□wâ°d-}. Apparently contains directional verbal suffix {-v̂°d-} 'along / hither' [Oswalt 1961: 186].

Segments: h ʧʰ o j iː ʧʼ
Comment: Morphophonemic shape {□hcʰo-yi°cʼ-}. Apparently consists of the root {□hcʰo-} 'to be absent, not to be' [Oswalt 1961: 334, 338] and the reflexive suffix {-yi°cʼ-} [Oswalt 1961: 196].
Borrowed from Lake Miwok hˈayu 'dog'.
Morphophonemic shape {□ʔqʼo-}.
Glossed as 'to get dry' in [Oswalt 1961: 99].
Polysemy: 'world / country / land / place / ground / dirt'.

Segments: ʔ i h pʰ u j
Comment: Glossed as 'grease' in [Oswalt 1964], as 'fat' in [Oswalt 1961].
Glossed as 'flight feather' in [Oswalt 1961: 20].
Polysemy: 'heat / fire / light'. Also functions as an adjective: 'hot / bright'.
Morphophonemic shape {□ca-}.
Polysemy: 'foot (body part) / foot (unit of measurement)'.
Morphophonemic shape {cuṭʼa°q-}.
Glossed as 'to give one'. Cf. čoʔdoq- 'to give several' [Oswalt 1961: 182].
Cf. the verbal root ʔqʼoʔdi- 'to do permanently, to do for good' [Oswalt 1961: 152].

Segments: ʦʼ a qʰ aː l a
Comment: Polysemy: 'green / blue'.
Glossed in [Oswalt 1961: 20] as 'hair of the head'.
Morphophonemic shape {□šo°c-}.

Segments: ʦʼ u h k u l

Comment: Subjective form. Morphophonemic shape {□ʔa: ~ □ʔa}. The allomorph ʔaː occurs in isolation or before an enclitic. Elsewhere, ʔa is usually used, but ʔaː is also possible. Objective form: oː ~ o (morphophonemic shape {□toː ~ □to}; distribution of long and short allomorphs same as in the subjective form).
Objective form.

Polysemy: 'to kill / to beat up'. Morphophonemic shape {pʰa=kʼu-°m-}. Apparently contains the instrumental prefix pʰa= 'with the end of a long object, with the fist' [Oswalt 1961: 144] and 'supraterrestrial' suffix {-°m-} ("...usually means that the action takes place in one spot off the ground or floor, but it also has diverse abstract meanings") [Oswalt 1961: 158].

Segments: ʔ d uː ʧ i ʧʼ
Comment: Morphophonemic shape {□ʔduːcicʼ-}.

This verb belongs to the following set of forms: mi=ti- 'one to be lying on the ground or floor', ba=ti- 'several to be lying on the ground or floor', mi=ma- 'one to be lying on a bed', ba=ma- 'several to be lying on a bed' [Oswalt 1961: 161]. Apparently, mi= and ba= are unproductive prefixes.

Segments: ʔ a h q o l

Comment: Another candidate is biteš 'head louse' [Oswalt 1961: 26]. The gloss 'head louse' for biteš, however, may be a mistake, since [McLendon 1973: 80] glosses ʔahči as 'head louse' and biteš as 'body louse'.

Segments: h i ʔ b a j a

Comment: Polysemy: 'deer / meat'. Distinct from cʼiʔi 'flesh' [Oswalt 1964: 424-425; Oswalt 1961: 24].

Segments: qʼ a l aː ʃ a

Comment: Polysemy: 'hill / mountain'.

Segments: ʃ i h ʧ i m aː ʧʼ
Comment: Morphophonemic shape {□šihcima°cʼ-}. Cited in [Oswalt 1961: 266] as šihčimaʔ (morphophonemic shape {šihcima°c-ʔ}) 'to name / naming / name' - absolutive (nominal form) of the verb 'to name'. Synchronically the verb stem {□šihcima°c-} is unanalysable, but comparative Pomoan evidence suggests that the historical root is {□ši-}. We can tentatively identify the semelfactive suffix {-hci-} [Oswalt 1961: 165]. Remaining part of the stem is formally identical to the directional suffix {-ma°c-} 'in hence' [Oswalt 1961: 189], but this may be a chance resemblance.
Negative enclitic. The other means of negation in Kashaya is the verbal suffix -ʰ- 'negative' [Oswalt 1961: 234].
Morphophonemic shape {□hku}.
Glossed as 'man' in [Oswalt 1961: 86]. Morphophonemic shape {ʔaca°c}.
Morphophonemic shape {□kʼi°s}.
Cf. the verb ʔda- (morphophonemic shape {□ʔda-}) 'to extend (of a path or road)' [Oswalt 1961: 224].
Source: Glossed as 'path' in [Oswalt 1964: 426-427] and as 'road / path' in [Oswalt 1961: 306]

p o l oː l o

Comment: Morphophonemic shape {□cad-}.

Comment: Borrowed from Spanish semilla.
Glossed as 'one to be sitting' in [Oswalt 1961: 161]. Morphophonemic shape {□ca-}. Cf. hihkoč- 'several to be sitting' [ibid.].
Morphophonemic shape {sima°q-}. Derived from the noun sima 'sleep' with the verbalizing suffix {-â°q-} [Oswalt 1961: 126].
Morphophonemic shape {□hosa}. A compound with ʔoho 'fire' as a first component.
Glossed in [Oswalt 1961: 181] as 'one to stand (on feet)'. Morphophonemic shape {□tʼe°t-}. Cf. qohqʰo- 'several to stand'; čoho- 'to stand (as a tree or post does)' [ibid.].
Glossed as 'rock' in [Oswalt 1961: 45].
Morphophonemic shape {□ciw-}. Cf. čiy- 'several to crawl or swim as a group' [Oswalt 1961: 182].
Source: Cited in [Oswalt 1964: 426-427] as ʔahqʰa čiw- 'swim' (ʔahqʰa means 'water') and in [Oswalt 1961: 182] as čiw- 'one to crawl or swim'

Comment: The Kashaya system of demonstratives includes three members: 1) muː ~ mu (morphophonemic shape {□muː ~ □mu}; objective form {□mul}) 'that, this, it, those, these, they (vague demonstrative or anaphoric reference)', 2) maʔu (objective form maʔal) 'this, these (the closer object)', 3) haʔu (objective form haʔal) 'that, those (the further object)' [Oswalt 1961: 112].
See notes on 'that'.
Subjective form. Morphophonemic shape {□ma}. Objective form: mi-o.
A compound whose first component haː= means 'in the mouth'.
Morphophonemic shape {□qʰoː}.
Morphophonemic shape {□w- ~ □-}. Cf. pʰil- 'several to go in a group' [Oswalt 1961: 225].
Source: Glossed as 'one to go' in [Oswalt 1961: 181, 224] and as 'walk' in [Oswalt 1964: 426-427]

Comment: Polysemy: 'hot / bright'. Also functions as a noun 'heat / fire / light'.
Subjective form. Morphophonemic shape {□ya}. Objective form: ya-l {□ya-l}.
Cited as baqʼˈo 'what / nothing (with the negative verb)' in [Oswalt 1961: 338].

Glossed as 'earthworm'.

Segments: ʧ ˈo t̪ʼ ə ʃ ə b a
Comment: The form was recorded by A. Halpern in non-phonemicized transcription.
Example sentences such as 'All those five large rocks rolled downward' [O'Connor 1987: 11] show that the word can function as 'all = omnis'.
A compound of no 'dust' and ho 'fire' [McLendon 1973: 66].

An alternative candidate is tʰiy 'big' [O'Connor 1987: 246]. Cf. the following sentences: "She is bigger (mato) than her horse is", "Her feet are bigger (tʰiy) than her horse's feet" [ibid.]. According to O'Connor, "[t]he difference in the adjectives glossed "big" results in the shape and dimensions of the objects being compared" [ibid.].

For morphological segmentation, cf. related adjective bala-m 'bloodshot,  bruised'. According to [O'Connor 1987: 24], suffixes -y and -m in these words are historically identical with verbal aspectual suffixes -y 'perfective' and -m 'durative / essive'.
Glossed as 'chest'. Distinct from ʼo 'breasts' [Oswalt 1964: 424-425].
Glossed as 'claw'.
Cited in [O'Connor 1987: 45, 74] as kʼala 'die sg.', cf. ley 'die coll.' [O'Connor 1987: 45, 74].
Borrowed from Lake Miwok hˈayu 'dog'.
-či is the semelfactive aspect suffix [O'Connor 1987: 30].
Glossed as 'ground' in [O'Connor 1987: 91, 226].
Glossed as 'grease'.
Polysemy: 'fire / hot'.
Cited as pʰid 'to be suspended in air, to fly' in [O'Connor 1987: 29].
Cf. ho- 'give (lengthy object)' [O'Connor 1987: 49, 163, 191, 240, 278], poʔo- 'give pl.' [O'Connor 1987: 240].
Cited as kʼedi 'good' in [O'Connor 1987: 79].
Glossed as 'blue' in [O'Connor 1987: 253].
Cited by O'Connor as ʔeː 'hair' [O'Connor 1987: 242, 251, 254] and ʔey 'hair' [O'Connor 1987: 245].
Distinct from šaː 'arm' [O'Connor 1987: 244].
Cited as šowʔ 'hear' in [O'Connor 1987: 31, 47, 56, 218]. -či is the semelfactive aspect suffix [O'Connor 1987: 30].
1st singular pronoun has agent case ʔaː, patient case oː, and oblique case oʔ ~  kʰe [O'Connor 1987: 158].
Patient case.
Glossed in [O'Connor 1987: 74] as 'kill sg.', cf. di=ley 'kill coll.' (instrumental prefix di= and root ley 'die pl.') [ibid.].
Glossed in [O'Connor 1987: 74] as 'lie sg.', cf. pʰoh 'lie coll.' [ibid.].
Glossed as 'head louse' in [McLendon 1973: 80]. Distinct from bitˈiš 'body louse' [ibid.].
Glossed as 'copious / abundant' in [O'Connor 1987: 39, 241].
Polysemy: 'deer / meat'. Distinct from cʼiʔˈi 'flesh' [Oswalt 1964: 424-425].
Glossed as 'mountain / hill' in [O'Connor 1987: 7, 231].
Cf. the verb ši-ʔ 'to name, to call someone something' [O'Connor 1987: 31].

Negative particle, used before the negated verb. Cooccurs with the negative verbal suffix -nha. Historically identical to the noun kʼo 'thing' [O'Connor 1987: 32]. Alternative candidate: negative verbal suffix ʰin (apparently sometimes functions as an independent particle) [Oswalt 1964: 426-427; O'Connor 1987: 31, 37, 48, 63, 162, 165, 280]. We tentatively choose kʼo because of its status as an independent word.

Segments: b i ʃ ˈe m aː
Comment: Cf. the verb bišˈema 'to rain' [O'Connor 1987: 46].
Cited by O'Connor as acʼ 'red' [O'Connor 1987: 42], tʼac 'red' [O'Connor 1987: 79], and ʼacʼ 'red' [O'Connor 1987: 163].
Glossed as 'path'.
Glossed by O'Connor as 'sit sg.', cf. pʰočam 'sit pl.' [O'Connor 1987: 74, 118].
Cited as siːyan 'skin' in [O'Connor 1987: 240].
Frequently occurs as a part of the compound verb sima miti 'to sleep' [O'Connor 1987: 35, 36, 38, 42, 85, 178, 226] (cf. miti 'to lie'). Sima 'to sleep' can be used alone [O'Connor 1987: 68].
Cited by O'Connor as bičʼu 'small' [O'Connor 1987: 159] and bicʼu 'small' [O'Connor 1987: 160, 227].
Cf. ho=saha 'smoke' [O'Connor 1987: 250] - a compound with ho 'fire' as a first part.

Segments: kʼ o t̪ ˈa m a

Comment: 2nd singular pronoun has agent case ma, patient case mi-o, and oblique case mi-ʔ [O'Connor 1987: 158].
A compound with ha 'mouth' as a first part.
Glossed as 'go (sg.)'. Cf. waː-d 'to walk (sg.)' [O'Connor 1987: 22] (cited as waːdˈe 'walk' in Oswalt 1964: 426-427) and pʰilaː-d 'to walk, collective' [O'Connor 1987: 71].
Polysemy: 'fire / hot'.
1st plural pronoun has agent case ya, patient case ya-l, and oblique case ya-ʔ [O'Connor 1987: 158].
The meaning 'what?' is expressed by kʼo 'thing', used with the question clitic a [O'Connor 1987: 315-316].
Used with the question clitic a [O'Connor 1987: 62, 316].

Glossed as 'chest'. Distinct from siːdˈoː 'breast / breast milk' [McLendon 1996: 542]. Cf. also kuːnˈu 'upper chest' [McLendon 1996: 543].

Glossed as 'to burn (animate subject)'. Plural stem: šaː=lˈo-ʼ-maː. The verb pʰaː=bˈe-kʰ, adduced in the glossary under 'to burn' [McLendon 1996: 542], means 'get burned' [McLendon 1996: 534] and is therefore ineligible.
Polysemy: 'claw / fingernail'.

Segments: q ˈoː j u h u
Comment: This verb, absent in the glossary, is attested in several examples in the grammar sketch: "When did you come?" [McLendon 1996: 528], "When are you going to come?" [ibid.], "May you come; I hope you will come" [McLendon 1996: 531], "I got sick, that's why I didn't come" [McLendon 1996: 539]. The verb contains the directional preverb qˈoːy= 'something previously unseen to appear' [McLendon 1996: 535].
Polysemy: 'to die / dead'. Contains the instrumental prefix muː= 'from internal energy or motivation' [McLendon 1996: 518].
Borrowed from Lake Miwok hˈayu 'dog'.
Plural stem: kʼaːlˈol-a.
Glossed as 'country, land, ground'. Cf. also aː 'land (as opposed to water)' [McLendon 1996: 514].
Secondary synonym: qaː=wˈaː-l 'to eat by chewing'.

Plural stem: pʰuː=bˈeː-l.
Polysemy: 'foot / hoof'. Distinct from šaːkˈo 'leg' [McLendon 1996: 546].
Another candidate is quːlˈaš 'full'. The difference between the two words is not explained in the glossary.

Glossed as 'to give (one thing)'. Alternative candidate: siː=xˈaː 'to give (one thing)' [ibid.]. Cf. also biː=dˈi-x 'to give (more than one thing)' [ibid.] and siː=lˈa-x 'to give on more than one occasion' [ibid.].
Plural: qʼoːdˈiy-a. Cf. also cʼiːqˈom 'delicious, sweet, good' [McLendon 1996: 543] and cʰiːkʰˈe=cʰiːkʰˌe 'id.' [ibid.]

Glossed as 'long / tall'. Plural stem: qˈola.
Glossed as 'head louse'. Distinct from pʰeːrˈeš 'body louse' [ibid.].

Glossed as 'back neck'. Another candidate is miːyˈaː 'throat / front neck' [McLendon 1996: 546, 549].

Segments: l ˈa b oː b o

Comment: Negative questions, requests, supplications, exhortations, and statements are all formed by placing the negative verb kʰúy- as the first, or more usually, the second, constituent of the negative sentence. The appropriate independent verb-forming suffixes are added to the negative verb, not the semantic main verb [McLendon 1996: 532].

Comment: Plural: siːmˈaː kuːʼˈeːm. See 'lie'.

Segments: ʔ ˈu j a x o
Comment: Cf. ʔˈuy 'eye' q.v.
Glossed as 'rock'.

The system of demonstrative pronouns in Eastern Pomo includes mˈe 'this, this one' (referent is close to speaker), ʔˈo 'that one, that one over there' (referent is at a distance from speaker) and bˈa 'that, that one' (referent is particular, at some distance, animate) [ibid.]. In the English - Eastern Pomo glossary 'that' is translated as bˈa [McLendon 1996: 549]. Nevertheless, we choose ʔˈo, because this pronoun does not require that its referent be animate.
See notes on 'that'.
Agentive stem. Oblique stem: mi.
Glossed as plural 'teeth'.

Comment: Plural stem: diː=kʰˈaː.

Cited as qʼlˈa-l-i-- in [Moshinsky 1970: 206].

There are two negative constructions depending on verbal aspect: 1) da VERB-o- 'negative (non-imperfective)' [Moshinsky 1970: 140] and 2) da VERB-s- 'negative imperfective' [Moshinsky 1970: 147] (cited as -da...s 'not' in [Oswalt 1964: 426-427]).

Alternative candidate: bhˈe-l-i- 'one swims' (root bhe- (sg., du.), mya- (pl.) 'motion through a fluid; swimming') [Moshinsky 1970: 106].

The Southeastern Pomo system of 3rd person pronouns and demonstratives includes the following members: ʔˈu-yi 'masculine, non-displaced (= visible), unmarked position', mˈi-yi 'masculine, non-displaced, near', ʔˈi-yi 'masculine, non-displaced, far', yˈi-wi 'masculine, displaced (= non-visible)', mˈe-med 'feminine, non-displaced, near', ʔˈo-med 'feminine, non-displaced, unmarked position', yˈi-med 'feminine, displaced' [Moshinsky 1970: 173]. We tentatively choose ʔˈi-yi and mˈi-yi as basic forms for 'that' and 'this' respectively. Oswalt lists ʔuy 'that' [Oswalt 1964: 426-427].
See notes on 'that'.

Comment: Polysemy: 'all (omnis) / all (totus)'. Apparently consists of koː 'all / no more' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 149] and the emphatic particle βúɾa [Bright & Gehr 2005: 255].
Polysemy: 'ashes / dust / gray (as postpound)'.
Same word as 'skin' q.v.

Segments: β i ʃ β aː n

Comment: Polysemy: 'big / large'. Plural: kêːč-as. Cf. the bound stem =kaːm 'big / large' (Plural: =kaːm-sa) [Bright & Gehr 2005: 139], used in compounds instead of kêːč.

Alternate morphophonological variant of the stem: =paɾa-. Secondary synonym: =ax '(animal) to bite / to rend with the teeth / to kill' (not used of humans, snakes, or insects) [Bright & Gehr 2005: 31].

Segments: i k x á ɾ a m k u n i ʃ
Comment: Polysemy: 'black / dark'. Literally 'night-like': ikxáɾam 'night / darkness' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 81], -kúniš (suffix) 'like, similar to' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 153]. Secondary synonyms: kíp ikxáɾam 'black', literally 'like night', kíp imnak 'black', literally 'like charcoal' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 147]. Cf. the bound stem =miːf 'black', used in a number of compounds [Bright & Gehr 2005: 162].
Polysemy: 'blood / red (as a postpound)'.
Polysemy: 'chest / breast / heart'. Distinct from úːčič 'teat / (woman's) breast' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 238]. Identical with 'heart' q.v.

Polysemy: 'to set fire to (something) / to burn (something) / to burn down (as a house)'. Derived from =áːh 'to handle or carry fire' with the suffix -ka 'onto'. Another candidate is =iːn-kú-βaθ 'to burn (something)', derived from =íːn-ka- 'to burn' with the causative suffix -βaθ [Bright & Gehr 2005: 61].
Glossed as 'nail (of finger or toe)'. Cf. ixupk-ôː-č 'something stuck on flatways (not edgeways) / flat feathering (of an arrow) / fingernail (old name)' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 133-134].

Segments: p i k x á ɾ a m p a
Comment: Derived from =p=ikxáɾam-pa / =p=ikxáɾam-pu 'to get cloudy', lit. 'to be dark again' (=p= 'iterative', =ikxáɾam- 'night / dark', -pa / -pu 'denominative').
Polysemy: 'cold / cold weather'.
Another candidate is =áhoː 'to go / walk / travel / arrive (here)' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 8], translated as 'come' in the English-Karuk index [Bright & Gehr 2005: 294].

Alternate morphophonological variant of the stem: =im-.  Cf. also =táːnβa '(du.) to die' [Bright & Gehr 2005: ], =p=éːɾuːn-pa '(pl.) to die' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 180]. Secondary synonym: =taːníha 'to be spoiled / (persons) to die / (the world) to come to an end' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 209].
Polysemy: 'dog / horse'. Secondary synonym: tiβáɾaɾih 'hound / dog', lit. 'ear-hanging' (tíːβ 'ear', βáɾaɾih 'to hang') [Bright & Gehr 2005: 231].

Segments: i β á x ɾ a h
Comment: Glossed as 'dry / dried up'. Alternate morphophonological variant of the stem: iβ=axɾaha-. Cf. =iβáxɾah 'to be dry' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 129], axɾah 'dead tree' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 34], =suβáxɾah 'to spread out to dry' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 208], =ixɾah 'to thirst for' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 133], =taxɾáhiš / =taxɾáhišɾih- 'to dry up' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 218], =θaɾáxɾah 'to be thirsty' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 222]. Morphological segmentation of these forms is not clear.
Cf. =θitiβ / =θitim- 'to hear' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 225].

Segments: i θ í β θ aː n eː n
Comment: Polysemy: 'country / earth / land / world'. Lit. 'lying-around' (=θiβ '(one inanimate object) to lie / be' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 225], θaːnêːn 'around' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 220]).
Alternate morphophonological variant of the stem: =am-.
Polysemy: 'round / egg / counter stick in Indian cards'. Cf. =úɾu- 'to swell'.

Segments: a θ k ú ɾ i t
Comment: Meaning glossed as 'fat, grease'.
Polysemy: 'fire / lantern / electric light / electricity'. Cf. =aha- 'to burn' (bound stem) [Bright & Gehr 2005: 7].
According to the dictionary, '[u]sed as a generic term'. An obvious English loanword.

Cf. =iθ=xip '(du.) to fly' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 124], =í=xip- '(pl.) to fly, to move through the air' (bound stem) [Bright & Gehr 2005: 132], =ip=xip 'to fly again / to fly back' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 106] (with the iterative prefix =ip=).
Polysemy: 'foot / toe / track / foot (measure word, twelve inches)'.
Alternate morphophonological variant of the stem: axyaɾa-. Cf. =axyaɾ / =axyan- '(contents) to fill (a container)'.

Polysemy: 'to give (something) to (someone) / to pay'. Cf. =iph-ih / =iph-ihi- 'to give (two objects) to (someone)' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 100], =ák-ih 'to give things, or a mass of something, to someone / to feed' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 10] (-ih / -ihi- is a benefactive suffix).
Polysemy: 'good / well'. Plural form: yêːpša(s) 'good ones'.

Segments: θ ú k i n k u n i ʃ
Comment: Polysemy: 'blue / green / yellow'. Literally 'like bile', from θúkin 'gall / bile / (in compounds) blue, green, yellow' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 228]. Secondary synonym: píɾiš-kuniš 'green', literally: 'like grass' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 189].

Segments: í f u n i h
Comment: Alternate morphophonological variant of the stem: if-unih-a-. Literally: 'growing down' (=if 'to grow', -unih 'down', -a ~ Ø 'deverbative'). Secondary synonym: iɾ / iɾa- 'hair of head' (according to [Bright & Gehr 2005: 106], an old word for ífunih).
Polysemy: 'hand / finger'.
Alternate morphophonological variant of the stem: =θitim-. Cf. tíːβ 'ear' q.v.

Polysemy: 'chest / breast / heart'. A second candidate is imyah / imyah-a- 'breath / heart' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 96], derived from =imyah 'to breathe'. Textual examples available in the dictionary suggest that iθβaːy is the main word for 'heart' as an anatomical term. Contexts for iθβaːy include: "I'll make that your heart will be hanging out, striped downwards" [Bright & Gehr 2005: 106], "That was his heart that popped" [Bright & Gehr 2005: 122], "Shoot him there by his big toe, his heart lies there" [Bright & Gehr 2005: 122]. For imyah we only have "He holds him against his heart (traditional Indian embrace)" [Bright & Gehr 2005: 183] and "My heart must lie good. (Said when eating first plant food in spring)" [Bright & Gehr 2005: 92].

Segments: β êː h ʃ u ɾ
Comment: Meaning glossed as 'horn (as of deer)'. Alternate morphophonological variant of the stem: βeːh-šuɾ-a- ~ βeː-šuɾ-a-. Derived from =βêːh-šuɾ / =βêːh-šuɾu- 'to stick outward', itself from =βêːh- 'to stick / to project' (bound stem). Cf. also =ʔáhaɾ- / =ʔahaɾa- 'horn' (according to [Bright & Gehr 2005: 7], an old term for βêːh-šuɾ); the latter is apparently a bound stem, occurring in itɾoːpa-ʔáhaɾ 'five-point buck', literally 'five-horn' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 128] and itahaɾa-ʔáhaɾ 'ten-point buck', literally 'ten-horn' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 118].

Meaning glossed as 'horn (as of deer)'. Alternate morphophonological variant of the stem: βeːh-šuɾ-a- ~ βeː-šuɾ-a-. Derived from =βêːh-šuɾ / =βêːh-šuɾu- 'to stick outward', itself from =βêːh- 'to stick / to project' (bound stem). Cf. also =ʔáhaɾ- / =ʔahaɾa- 'horn' (according to [Bright & Gehr 2005: 7], an old term for βêːh-šuɾ); the latter is apparently a bound stem, occurring in itɾoːpa-ʔáhaɾ 'five-point buck', literally 'five-horn' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 128] and itahaɾa-ʔáhaɾ 'ten-point buck', literally 'ten-horn' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 118].
Polysemy: 'to beat / to kill / to catch (fish)'. Alternate morphophonological variant of the stem: =iykáɾa-. Cf. =iyfip 'to kill game' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 135].

Segments: áː p u n m a
Comment: Polysemy: 'to know / to know about (a person or thing) / to find out'. Secondary synonyms: =ítap 'to know / to be familiar with / to recognize' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 119], =p=itap 'to know / meet / recognize' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 191], =xus / =xu- 'to think / to know / to realize / to feel' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 266]. Analysis of textual examples in [Bright & Gehr 2005] shows that =áːpunma is the basic synonym for the Swadesh meaning 'to know (of a situation)'.

Homonymous with sáːn 'big-leaf maple (Acer macrophyllum)' [ibid.]. Another candidate is píɾiš 'grass / leaf / bush / brush / plant (excluding trees) / "medicine", i.e. a preparation for magical purposes, not necessarily including plants' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 189].

Segments: i j ɾ úː h ɾ i β
Comment: Meaning glossed as '(sg.) to lie, to be in a lying position'. Alternate morphophonological variant of the stem: =iyɾúːh-ɾim-. Derived from =iyɾuh 'to coil / to revolve (something) / to roll (something)' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 136] with the suffix -ɾiβ / -ɾim 'at rest' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 197]. Cf. also =iphí-ɾiβ '(two) to lie, to be lying' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 100], =úɾu-ɾiβ / =úɾu-ɾim- '(pl. anim.) to lie' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 238], =θáːn-iβ / =θáːn-im- '(inanimate object) to sit, be / (animal or person) to lie, to be dead' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 200].
Polysemy: 'long / tall'. Cf. the bound stem =xáɾah 'long (of spatial measurement) / tall' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 261], used in compounds instead of βâːɾam.

Segments: á β a n s a
Comment: Meaning glossed as 'man (i.e. an adult human male)'. Derived from áβan 'husband'.
Polysemy: 'much / many / lots'.
Polysemy: 'meat / flesh / body'.

Segments: k úː s ɾ a h
Comment: Polysemy: 'sun / moon / month'. Cf. also the compound form ikxaɾám=kuːsɾa 'moon', literally 'night-sun' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 82].

Segments: t úː j ʃ i p
Comment: Polysemy: 'mountain / hill'. Derived from t=uːy 'mound' with the suffix -sip 'up'. Another candidate is uːy 'hill / mountain' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 241]. The nature of the prefixed t= in t=uːy is not clear.
Polysemy: 'mouth / beak (of a bird)'.
Alternate morphophonological variant of the stem: iθβuy-a-. Derived from =iθβuy 'to be named / to be called / to be worth'.
Polysemy: 'new / fresh'.

Segments: i k x á ɾ a m
Comment: Polysemy: 'night / darkness'.

The regular expression of negation within a verbal form usually consists of the prefix pu- and the suffix -aɾa, although the suffix is not added in past tense and certain other forms. With adjectival predicates, the form of the "circumfix" may be pu- ... -hara (e. g. pu=yáβ-hara "it's not good").
Polysemy: 'one / a certain / (in compounds) all, the whole'.
Polysemy: 'human being, person / Indian'. Alternate morphophonological variant of the stem: aɾa-ɾa-. Cf. also áɾa ~ áɾah 'person'.

Segments: p a θ ɾ i h
Comment: Alternate morphophonological variant of the stem: paθɾih-a-. Derived from the verb =paθɾih 'to rain'.

Segments: aː x k ú n i ʃ
Comment: Literally: 'like blood'. Secondary synonyms: áːx-hič 'red' (old word) [Bright & Gehr 2005: 4] (h may result from mistranscription), áx-ič 'red', literally 'little blood' (used in a few expressions) [Bright & Gehr 2005: 33].

Polysemy: 'trail / path / road'. Alternate morphophonological variant of the stem: impaha-. Secondary synonyms: impah-tíɾih 'road', literally 'wide path' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 91]; βeːkin-ʔímpaːh 'road', literally 'wagon-trail' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 247].
Polysemy: 'round / egg / counter stick in Indian cards'. Cf. =úɾu- 'to swell'.
Polysemy: 'dirt / sand'. Secondary synonyms: sáh=yuːx, literally 'river dirt' (sah= 'downhill') [Bright & Gehr 2005: 199]; yúx-naːm 'sand', literally 'flat dirt' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 279].
Irregular forms: =ipíti 'to be saying', =ipaːt 'said', =ipáheːn 'had said', =ipáːnik 'said long ago', =pêːš 'will say'.
Polysemy: 'to see / to find'.
Derived from úːh 'tobacco' with the diminutive suffix -iš. According to [Bright & Gehr 2005: 235], "[p]robably applied originally only to tobacco seed".

Polysemy: 'to live / to sit / to stay / to be / to be at home'. Alternate morphophonological variant of the stem: =ikɾiβ-. Cf. =kûːɾ- / =kûːn- 'to sit / to slide (on one's buttocks)' (bound stem, occurs with directional suffixes) [Bright & Gehr 2005: 157].
Same word as 'bark' q.v.

Segments: i k β íː t h a
Comment: Polysemy: 'to sleep / to fall asleep / to be sleepy'. According to [Bright & Gehr 2005: 79], probably contains suffix -ha 'denominative'. Cf. =ásiβ / =ásim- 'to lie down to sleep / to go to bed' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 26], translated simply as 'sleep' in several examples [Bright & Gehr 2005: 26, 36]

Segments: n îː n a m i ʧ
Comment: Meaning glossed as 'little / small'. According to Bright & Gehr, "replaced after nouns by =ʔanamahač". Plural form: tûːpič-as (=tunβêːč-(asa) after nouns).

Segments: i h j á ɾ i h
Comment: Glossed as '(animate) to stand, be standing'. Derived from =íːhya '(long object) to stand, be' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 59] with the suffix -ɾih 'up'.

Segments: a t á j r aː m
Comment: Could be formally analyzed as átay 'roe, salmon eggs' [ibid.] + (?) -raːm 'place' (locational morpheme) [Bright & Gehr 2005: 196], although the latter is normally used in verbals rather than nominals.
Polysemy: 'rock / stone / pit of fruit / earth, dirt (in some compounds)'. Alternate morphophonological variant of the stem: asa-.

Segments: k úː s ɾ a h
Comment: Polysemy: 'sun / moon / month'. Same word as 'moon' q.v.

Cf. =íθ=puh- '(two people) to swim' (bound stem) [Bright & Gehr 2005: 122], =ihtak- '(several) to swim' (bound stem) [Bright & Gehr 2005: 57]. Another candidate is =uːfíθ-βa 'to swim' (never used with directionals) [Bright & Gehr 2005: 239].

Meaning glossed as 'this, that (referring to something designated by pointing)'. Another candidate is βáː 'that / that way / he, she, it' (usually refers to something designated elsewhere in the linguistic context) [Bright & Gehr 2005: 242].
Meaning glossed as 'this, that (referring to something designated by pointing)'.
Alternate morphophonological variant of the stem: βuha-.
Cf. =iːp 'tree / bush' (only in compounds) [Bright & Gehr 2005: 61].
Cf. =iːp 'tree / bush' (only in compounds) [Bright & Gehr 2005: 61].

Polysemy: 'to go / to walk / to travel / to arrive (here)'. Other possible candidates: =uːm / =uːmu- 'to arrive (there) / to go (to a place)' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 239]; =βâːɾam / =βâːɾamu- 'to go / to go away / to leave' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 243].
Meaning glossed as 'hot (of objects)'. Alternate morphophonological variant of the stem: imfiɾa-. Cf. also =impuk '(objects) to be warm' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 91].

Polysemy: 'water / juice'. Literally 'that which is drunk', from the verb =iš 'to drink', q.v. Another candidate is áːs 'water / juice' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 3]. According to [Bright & Gehr 2005: 3, 108] the two words are equivalent. This is a clear case of "transit-synonymity": the "new" word íš-aha is in the process of replacing the "old" one, áːs.
Polysemy: 'water / juice'.
Polysemy: 'what? / something'. Alternate morphophonological variant of the stem: fata-.

Segments: ʧ á n ʧ aː f k u n i ʃ
Comment: Literally: 'like foam', from čánčaːf 'foam'. Replaced in compounds by =taːhkoː 'white' (derived from táːh 'snow') [Bright & Gehr 2005: 208]. Secondary synonym: taːh-kúniš 'white', literally: 'like snow' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 208].
Polysemy: 'who? / anyone'. Cf. also the phonetic variant akáɾay 'who' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 10], according to the dictionary, equivalent to akâːy.

Segments: a s i k t á β aː n
Comment: Polysemy: 'woman / female'. Literally: 'water-carrier', from áːs 'water', q.v., and =iktaβ / =iktam- 'to hold or carry in the hand / to carry (water)' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 76].

Segments: θ ú k i n k u n i ʃ
Comment: Polysemy: 'blue / green / yellow'. Literally: 'like bile', from θúkin 'gall / bile / blue, green, yellow (in compounds)' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 228]. Secondary synonym: kasčíːp-kuniš 'yellow', literally 'like porcupine quills (which are dyed yellow for basketry)' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 143], from kasčiːp 'porcupine / porcupine quills / yellow' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 143].
Alternate morphophonological variant of the stem: yiβu-.
Cf. =ipšéːk 'to be heavy' [Bright & Gehr 2005: 103].

Segments: ûː m u k i ʧ
Comment: Meaning glossed as 'near / close by'.

Segments: i p ʃ ûː n k i n a ʧ
Comment: Polysemy: 'short / low'.

Segments: i p ʃ ûː n k i n i ʧ
Comment: Polysemy: 'short / low'.

ID: Karuk_THIN (OF SHAPE OF OBJECT)_THIN (OF SHAPE OF OBJECT)_Karuk_1
Segments: x ú t n a h i ʧ
Comment: Polysemy: 'thin (as of fabric) / loose'. Secondary synonym: βaːs-kič 'thin', derived from βaːs 'blanket' with the suffix -kič 'like'. In the only textual example given in the dictionary, βaːs-kič is translated 'as thin as a blanket'. Possibly just a nonce word.

Segments: i k ɾ éː m j a h
Comment: Polysemy: 'wind / air'. Alternate morphophonological variant of the stem: ikɾeːmyaha-. Cf. the verb =ikɾéːmyah '(wind) to blow'.
Polysemy: 'worm / angleworm'.

Segments: h á ɾ i n a j
Comment: Cf. hâːɾi ~ háɾi 'sometime / at various times'. The nature of the element -nay is not clear.

Word class: pronoun. According to [Marlett 2000], there are three ways to express the notion of 'all' in Seri: 1) the intransitive verb k=kˈoːo 'whole, entire / all' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 174], typically occurring in dependent adverbial clauses; 2) the pronoun koː 'all', that may either stand alone or follow a noun phrase; 3) the adjective koː 'all / every' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 229], that occurs inside the noun phrase. The adjective typically modifies a singular noun and is used mainly in fixed expressions like 'every day', 'all the world' etc. The verb and the pronoun may be used in paraphrase relationship, e.g. the sentence "All of the dogs will go" may be translated either with the verb or with the pronoun. Both the verb and the pronoun may express the 'singular' ('totus') and the 'plural' ('omnis') meaning, but the pronoun is more often associated with the plural noun phrase, which is why we choose it for the wordlist.

Segments: ʔ a n t ˈi m a k
Comment: Plural: ʔant ˈimaxk. Literally 'middle of earth' (cf. ʔant 'earth / dirt / land' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 324], q.v. and ˈi=mak (possessed noun, plural: ˈi=ma[x]k) 'middle of' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 412]).

Polysemy: 'skin of a person / skin or hide of an animal / epidermis or bark of a plant or tree / skin or peel of a fruit or vegetable / shell of an egg / shell of a mollusk / exoskeleton of an arthropod / exterior part of a bottle or can / casing or shell of a bullet / body of an automobile'. The general meaning of this word is defined in the dictionary as 'the integral part of something that encases it'. Word class: possessed noun. Plural: i=nˈaːax. Same word as 'skin' q.v.
Glossed as 'belly, abdomen'. Word class: possessed noun. Plural: yˈa-kox. Secondary synonym: i=samˈon 'abdomen, belly and soft underside' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 427].
Glossed as 'large, big'. Word class: intransitive verb. Basic forms: 3 sg. t=ˈaːkox, 3 pl. t=aːkʷɬ. Antonym: k=ˈisiɬ 'small, little, miniature' q.v.
Word class: noun. Plural: šˈiːka-ɬk.

Segments: k k ˈa t χ ɬ a
Comment: Glossed as 'bite in anger (like dog)'. Word class: transitive verb. Basic forms: 3 sg. i=t=kˈatɬa, 3 pl. i=t=kˈatɬox. Secondary synonyms: k=kaɸš 'bite (with front teeth)' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 167], k=kat 'bite (large piece, as a shark does)' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 171], k=kˈaox 'bite with the front teeth' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 171], k=kˈašni 'bite (snake) / pinch (crab)' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 172]. We choose k=kˈatɬa as the main synonym because it suits the diagnostic contexts better. All the above words may contain a fossilized prefix ka= with the meaning 'do smth. with teeth'. The former existence of such a prefix may be further confirmed by the following verbs: k=kˈaːo 'chew / curse (with power to harm)' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 166], k=kˈanax 'chew with back teeth' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 169], k=kapxʷ 'chew (something juicy)' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 169], k=kap 'crack (hard thing, with teeth)' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 170], k=kˈašɬiɬ 'chew on to flatten' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 172]. It is worth noting that Terrence Kaufman reconstructs instrumental prepound *qa= 'by biting/chewing, with teeth/jaws' for Proto-Hokan on the basis of Northern Hokan data [Kaufman 1989: 123]. According to Kaufman's tables of phonetic correspondences [Kaufman 1989: 84-93], Proto-Hokan *qa= should have yielded ka= in Seri.
Word class: intransitive verb. Basic forms: 3 sg. t=ˈoːpoɬ; 3 pl. t=oːpɬ, t=ˈoːpɬ-ox. Secondary synonym: k=ʔɛːp 'deep black' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 179].

Word class: noun. Plural: ʔˈaːit-ɬox. In 19th century word lists the word is attested as avt ~ aat [Marlett 2010: 37], with the phoneme -w- or -v- that has been completely lost in modern Seri. Secondary synonyms: ˈiːka ˈano mˈoka 'blood' (literally: 'substance that comes'), archaic [Moser & Marlett 2010: 587], ˈiːka isˈɛːn oː kaːp 'blood' (literally: 'substance that is in the abdomen'), archaic [Moser & Marlett 2010: 588].
Polysemy: 'bone / rib / petiole / limb / branch / stem / skeleton or rib (of boat)'. Word class: possessed noun. Plural forms: 3 sg. possessor ˈi=ta[x]k, 3 pl. possessor ˈi=ta-x-ox.

Segments: ˈiː s a χ iː ʃ k
Comment: Glossed as 'breast / chest'. Plural: ˈiːsto ˈiːšxox. Composed of ˈiː=sa- (possessed noun, plural ˈiː=s-to-) (according to [Moser & Marlett 2010: 409], this word is no longer used as an independent noun, having been replaced by iʔˈiːsa 'breath / spirit / soul / life') and iː=šk 'front of body' (possessed noun, plural forms: 3 sg. possessor iː=š[x]k, 3 pl. possessor ˈiː=š-x-ox) [Moser & Marlett 2010: 411]. Secondary synonyms: i=mt 'breast / milk' (apparently denotes only or mainly female breast) [Moser & Marlett 2010: 415], i=snˈaːp 'breastmeat / chest' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 426], i=tɬˈɛːn 'palm of hand / chest area' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 434].

Segments: k a ʔ ˈi t a x
Comment: Polysemy: 'burn / turn on light, light (e.g., candle) / brand'. Word class: causative verb. Basic forms: pf. 3 sg. i=t=aʔ=ˈitax; impf. 3 sg. i=t=aʔ=ˈitaɬ-im, i=t=aʔ=ˈitaɬ-k; pf. 3 pl. i=t=aʔ=ˈitaɬ-kox; impf. 3 pl. i=t=aʔ=ˈitaɬ-am. Derived from the intransitive verb k=ˈitax 'burn' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 534]. Secondary synonym: k=ak=ˈaːnox (causative verb) 'burn / light (e.g. candle) / fish by torchlight' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 87], derived from k=ˈanox 'happen of a continuous and rather low sound, like the roaring of the sea; the hissing of a lantern; or the buzzing of a bee / burn with a hissing sound' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 131].
Polysemy: 'fingernail / claw'. Word class: possessed noun. Plural: i=nˈoːs-ɬka.

Segments: ʔ ˈoː k a ɬ a
Comment: Glossed as 'cloud, especially small scattered clouds'. Word class: noun. Plural: ʔˈoːka-ɬa. Cf. ʔˈoːka- 'large thunder cloud' (plural ʔˈoːk-ta-) [ibid.]. -ɬa is tentatively considered a suffix due to comparison with ʔˈoːka-.
Word class: intransitive verb. Basic form: t=aːpɬ.

Word class: intransitive verb. Basic forms: pf. 3 sg. mˈo=t=a; impf. 3 sg. mˈo=t=a-tim; pf. 3 pl. mˈo=t=a-t; impf. 3 pl. mˈo=t=a-toɬka, mˈo=t=a-tox. According to [Moser & Marlett 2010: 445], prefix mo= "[o]ccurs with only a few verbs to indicate that the subject is approaching".

Segments: ʔ a k χ k m iː ʔ
Comment: Polysemy: 'lost (object) / die (person)'. Formed from the intransitive verb k=m=iːʔ 'scarce, rare' (basic forms: pf. 3 sg. t=m=iːʔ, pf. 3 pl. t=m=ˈiːʔ-tox, impf. 3 pl. t=m=ˈiːʔ-toɬka) [ibid.] with the adverb ʔak 'apart, alone' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 313]. According to [Moser & Marlett 2010: 186], k=m=iːʔ is historically related to k=iːʔ 'be' (m= is the negative prefix). Secondary synonym: k=ˈoːi 'die (especially animal) / fade' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 230]. This verb is also used in idiomatic expressions meaning '(to be) thirsty', '(to be) hungry', 'to be eclipsed (moon, sun)' etc. It is highly probable that k=ˈoːi is the original word for 'to die (of person)', replaced by ʔak k=m=iːʔ. However, textual examples in the dictionary leave no doubt that ʔak k=m=iːʔ is now the main synonym.
Word class: possessed noun. Plural: ʔˈa=a-ka. Secondary synonym: šiː ʔˈɛmɛ ˈiːkot kˈata 'dog' (archaic), literally: 'thing that walks between the houses' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 625].

Polysemy: 'drink / bite and suck (e.g. mosquito)'. Word class: transitive verb. Basic forms: pf. 3 sg. i=t=ˈasi, impf. 3 sg. i=t=ˈas-yat, pf. 3 pl. i=t=ˈas-yox, impf. 3 pl. i=t=ˈas-yoɬka. Secondary synonym: k=i=m 'swallow / drink' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 512-513]. Cf. also the detransitivized verb k=ˈoː=si 'drink', derived from k=ˈi=si [Moser & Marlett 2010: 227].

Segments: kʷ k ˈoː t i x
Comment: Polysemy: 'dry / used up (liquid) / die (plant)'. Word class: intransitive verb. Basic forms: 3 sg. kʷ=t=ˈoːtix, 3 pl. kʷ=t=ˈoːtiɬ-k. Secondary synonyms: k=axʷk 'dry' (intransitive verb), archaic [Moser & Marlett 2010: 121], k=oːskɬ 'dry / speckled or mottled without much color' (intransitive verb) [Moser & Marlett 2010: 227], k=paps 'dry (lacking liquid for appropriate use) / rough (surface)' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 244].
Glossed as 'outer ear'. Word class: possessed noun. Plural: ˈi=sɬ-ox.

Polysemy: 'earth, dirt, land / world, earth / place / year / weather'. Word class: noun. Cf. ʔamt 'ground / loose soil / sand' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 322]. According to [Marlett 2010: 18], the distinction between ʔant and ʔamt is relatively recent: 19th century word lists have only ʔamt in all meanings, including 'year'.

Word class: transitive verb. Basic forms: pf. 3 sg. i=t=ˈaʔit, impf. 3 sg. i=t=ˈaʔit-im, pf. 3 pl. i=t=ˈaːit-ox, impf. 3 pl. i=t=ˈaːit-oɬka. Cf. also the detransitivized verb k=ˈoː=ʔit 'eat', derived from k=ˈi=ʔit [Moser & Marlett 2010: 218].
Word class: possessed noun. Plural: iː=p. Secondary synonym: šiːk ʔant okˈaːi 'egg (of bird)', literally 'that which a bird lays' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 615].

Polysemy: 'eye / knothole / headlight (of automobile)'. Word class: possessed noun. Plural forms: 3 sg. possessor ˈi=to-x, 3 pl. possessor ˈi=to-ɬkox. Secondary synonym: i=ʔ=ˈiːxim 'eye', archaic (derived from k=ˈiːxim 'have sight') [Moser & Marlett 2010: 397].

Word class: deverbal noun (action/oblique). Derived from the intransitive verb k=ʔa 'stained with grease / full of grease or fat, greasy' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 178]. Another candidate is ˈi=pom 'firm fat (of animal)' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 423].

Polysemy: 'hair (not on the head of humans) / fur / feather'. The general meaning of this word is defined in the dictionary as 'relatively soft structures that grow from the skin of animals'. Word class: possessed noun. Plural: ˈi=na-ta.
Polysemy: 'fire / lamp / star (archaic)'. Word class: noun. Plural: ʔamˈak-x.

Segments: ʃ i χ k ˈa m
Comment: Polysemy: 'fish / a category of marine animals that includes fish, sharks, rays, dolphins, and whales'. Word class: noun. Plural: ši=kˈam. Compound based on šiː 'thing' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 616] and k=kam 'alive' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 168], literally 'thing that is alive'. Secondary synonym: šiː kipˈasi 'fish' (archaic), literally 'thing that has meat' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 631].
Glossed as 'fly, move through space'. Word class: intransitive verb. Basic forms: pf. 3 sg. t=kap, impf. 3 sg. t=kˈap-tim, pf. 3 pl. t=kˈap-tox, impf. 3 pl. t=kˈap-toɬka.

Polysemy: 'leg and foot / hind leg (of animal) / toe'. Word class: possessed noun. Plural forms: 3 sg. possessor i=tˈoːit, 3 pl. possessor i=tˈoaː-tx. In 19th century word lists the word is attested as itóva, itoba [Marlett 2010: 40], with the phoneme -w- or -v-, completely lost in modern Seri. Secondary synonym: i=mˈon-x 'foot' (archaic) [Moser & Marlett 2010: 414]. The meaning 'foot' (as opposed to 'leg') is expressed by itˈoaː atx [ibid.] (the second component is identical to at-x 'reef' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 579]).

Glossed as 'full (container)'. Word class: intransitive verb. Basic forms: pf. 3 sg. t=pokt, impf. 3 sg. t=pˈokat-im, pf. 3 pl. t=pˈokat-ox. Secondary synonym: k=kam 'full' (intransitive verb) [Moser & Marlett 2010: 169] (textual examples: 'I ate something and I'm full' [ibid.], 'When he eats and gets full, he burps' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 497]).

Glossed as 'give (gift)'. Word class: irregular transitive verb. "The direct object is the recipient. The gift can be mentioned." Secondary synonyms: k=ˈi=kɛ 'give (gift)' ("The direct object is the gift. The recipient cannot be mentioned.") [Moser & Marlett 2010: 525], k=ˈɛkɛ 'give (gift-wise)' ("Neither the item nor the recipient is mentioned.") [Moser & Marlett 2010: 480], kʷ=k=akˈo=š--ot 'give' (derived from k=akˈo=š--ot 'help carry', itself derived from k=ˈaːši 'carry'. "This verb requires a singular indirect object that indicates the recipient of the object.") [Moser & Marlett 2010: 97], kʷ=k=akˈo=ɛtoɬ 'give (something, to someone)' (derived from k=ɛːɬ 'buy') [Moser & Marlett 2010: 279]. Analysis of textual examples in the dictionary leaves no doubt that ˈiː=k=ɛ is the main synonym for 'to give'.
Polysemy: 'good / be well, get well'. Word class: intransitive verb. Basic forms: pf. 3 sg. t=ˈiːpɛ, impf. 3 sg. t=ˈiːpɛ-tim, pf. 3 pl. t=iːp-t, impf. 3 pl. t=ˈiːp-tox. Variant: k=ˈiːpi.

Polysemy: 'blue, green / tender (like branch) / green (not ripe)'. Word class: intransitive verb. Basic forms: 3 sg. t=ˈoːiɬ, 3 pl. t=ˈoːiɬ-o. In 19th century word lists the word is attested as kovìlch, kobslh [Marlett 2010: 56], with the phoneme -w- or -v-, completely lost in modern Seri. Secondary synonym: panˈaːms yˈaːiɬ kʷkˈoːiɬ 'green', literally 'blue/green like blue/green colour of seaweed' [ibid.].
Polysemy: 'head / hair of head'. Word class: possessed noun. Plural: i=ɬˈit-kox. Secondary synonym: i=tˈaːi (possessed noun) 'hair of head', archaic [Moser & Marlett 2010: 428].

Polysemy: 'finger / hand / forearm / upper arm of a person / paw / foreleg of an animal / tentacle of a squid or octopus / cheliped of a crab or lobster / arm of a columnar cactus / thick branch of a tree / sleeve of an article of clothing / upper part of a boat'. All but the last meanings are summarized in the dictionary as 'relatively thick lateral extension of the upper of front part of something, such as the forelimb of an animal or person, or an important part of it'. Word class: possessed noun. Plural forms: i=nɬ-ˈaš 'fingers', i=nɬ 'hands', ˈi=nɬ-ox 'arms'.
Polysemy: 'head / hair of head'. Word class: possessed noun. Plural: i=ɬˈit-kox. Same word as 'hair' q.v.
Polysemy: 'hear / understand'. Word class: transitive verb. Basic forms: pf. 3 sg. i=t=ˈiː, impf. 3 sg. i=t=ˈiː-tim, pf. 3 pl. i=t=ˈiːi.
Word class: possessed noun. Plural: i=mxʷk.

Segments: i t ˈaː m a ɬ k a
Comment: Polysemy: 'antenna (of lobster or insect) / horn, horns / antler, antlers'. Word class: possessed noun. Plural: 3 pl. possessor i=tˈaːmaɬk-ox.

Polysemy: 'I / we'. Word class: pronoun. In 19th century word lists the first person singular pronoun 'I' differs from the plural 'we' and is attested as ive, ibe, ivve ~ ove, ivé [Marlett 2010: 32]. Cf. ʔatˈɛː 'I (emphatic), I think, as far as I'm concerned' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 356].

Word class: transitive verb. Basic forms: pf. 3 sg. i=t=ˈakʷ, impf. 3 sg. i=t=ˈako-tim, pf. 3 pl. i=t=ˈakʷ-t, impf. 3 pl. i=t=ˈakʷ-tox. Secondary synonyms: ʔak k=a=m=ˈiːʔit 'kill (a person)' (causative of ʔak k=m=iːʔ 'die', q.v.) [Moser & Marlett 2010: 126], k=aʔ=ˈinɛx 'kill, massacre, wipe out, make extinct' (causative of k=ˈinɛx '(be) empty') [Moser & Marlett 2010: 109], k=ˈoː=ikʷ 'kill' (detransitive of k=i=kʷ) [Moser & Marlett 2010: 219], ikˈiːsa šo kakˈapat 'kill', literally 'make his spirit fly' (rare) [Moser & Marlett 2010: 89-90].
Word class: possessed noun. Plural forms: 3 sg. possessor i=ɸɬk, 3 pl. possessor ˈi=ɸaɬk-ox.
Polysemy: 'know / be able to / do repeatedly'. Word class: irregular transitive verb. Basic forms: pf. 3 sg. i=t=ˈaː, pf. 3 pl. i=t=ˈaː-x, impf. 3 pl. i=t=ˈaː-xam.
Word class: possessed noun. Plural: i=stx, ˈi=staɬ-ka.

Polysemy: 'lie down, be lying down / be (lying down)'. Word class: irregular intransitive verb. Basic forms: pf. 3 sg. t=oːm; impf. 3 sg. t=ˈoːmam; pf. 3 pl. t=ˈoːiti; impf. 3 pl. t=ˈoiː-tox, t=ˈoiː-toɬka.
Word class: possessed noun. Plural: ˈi=yas-ox.

Segments: k ˈa kʷ s χ a x
Comment: Polysemy: 'long / tall'. Word class: intransitive verb. Basic forms: 3 sg. t=ˈakʷsax, 3 pl. t=ˈakʷɬa. Secondary synonym: toː kˈiyat 'long', from toː 'far away' and k=ˈiyat 'reach' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 545].
Glossed as 'head louse'. Word class: possessed noun. Plural: iː-t. Absolutive: ʔa=i. Distinct from i=sk 'body louse' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 425].
Polysemy: 'man / male / larger or longer item (such as long projectile point, tall boojum, or tall barrel cactus)'. Word class: noun. Plural: ktam-kʷ, (archaic) ktˈamo-xox.
Polysemy: 'many / much / abundant'. Word class: intransitive verb. Basic forms: 3 sg. t=ˈato; 3 pl. t-ˈato-x, t=ˈato-xam.

Segments: i p χ ˈa s i
Comment: Polysemy: 'meat / flesh / soft part of plant'. Word class: possessed noun. Plural: i=pˈaš.
Polysemy: 'moon / month / moonfish (Selene spp.)'. Word class: noun. Plural: ˈiːš-to-.
Polysemy: 'rock, stone / hill / mountain'. Word class: noun. Plural: ʔˈasat-ox. Identical with 'stone' q.v.

Glossed as 'opening, inside of mouth'. Word class: possessed noun. Plural: i=tˈɛːn-kox. Secondary synonym: ˈi=ta 'mouth (of animal or thing)', archaic [Moser & Marlett 2010: 428]. The following example shows that the latter word can also be applied to human mouth: ˈIta ʔant imˈoːit ˈiʔa 'He talks too much' (literally, 'His mouth doesn't close') [ibid.].
Word class: possessed noun. Plural: i=tˈaːsi-tox.
Word class: possessed noun. Plural: yˈaːp-kox.

Segments: k m aː k iː ʔ
Comment: Literally 'to be now'. Cf. the adverb kmaː 'now' (a variant of kmaː 'id.' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 181]) and the intransitive verb k=iːʔ 'be' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 496]).

Segments: i ʔ ˈa m o k
Comment: Word class: deverbal noun (action/oblique). Derived from the intransitive impersonal verb k=ʔˈamok 'become night' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 177-178].
Polysemy: 'nose / beak'. Word class: possessed noun. Plural: ˈiː=ɸ-kox. Absolutive: ʔaː=ɸ.
Negative verbal prefix.

Word class: adjective. Cf. the intransitive verb k=ˈašox 'alone / be one' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 160-161] and the interjection tˈoːxom 'one' (an archaic word, used only in counting) [Moser & Marlett 2010: 571].

Segments: ʃ iː χ k ˈiː s a χ
Comment: Plural: ˈiːka kˈiːsto. Literally: 'thing that has life' (cf. šiː 'thing' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 616] and k=ˈiː=sa- 'have life' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 507]). Secondary synonyms: kmˈiːkɛ 'Seri (person) / person (in limited contexts)' (plural komkˈaːk) [Moser & Marlett 2010: 187], k=ˈoː=p-tim 'person', archaic (subject noun, derived from k=oː=p 'dig out (using tool) / stitch a basket') [Moser & Marlett 2010: 225].
Word class: deverbal noun (action/oblique). Derived from the intransitive impersonal verb k=ˈapka 'rain, precipitate' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 135].

Word class: intransitive verb. Basic forms: 3 sg. t=ʔɛːɬ, 3 pl. t=ʔɛːɬ. Apparently derived from ʔɛːɬ 'purple prickly pear (Opuntia gosseliniana)' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 368-369]. In 19th century word lists the word is attested as kevilch, kebls [Marlett 2010: 56], with the phoneme -w- or -v-, completely lost in modern Seri. Secondary synonyms: k=kiʔxʷ 'red' (intransitive verb, basic forms: 3 sg. t=tiʔxʷ, 3 pl. t=tˈiʔxʷ-ɬka) [Moser & Marlett 2010: 252], k=ˈaktox 'red', archaic (intransitive verb, basic forms: 3 sg. t=ˈaktox, 3 pl. t=ˈakto-ɬka) [Moser & Marlett 2010: 98].
Word class: noun. Plural: ʔˈaːʔo-ɬkam.
Polysemy: 'root (of plant, of tongue) / base (of hill), foundation (of house)'. Word class: possessed noun. Plural: i=ˈaːi-kox, i=ˈaː-koɬ.

ID: Seri_SPHERICAL (ROUND IN THREE DIMENSIONS)_SPHERICAL (ROUND IN THREE DIMENSIONS)_Seri_1
Segments: k t ˈo k n i x
Comment: Glossed as 'round, spherical'. Word class: intransitive verb. Basic forms: 3 sg. t=tˈoknix, 3 pl. t=tˈokna-ɬka.

ID: Seri_CIRCULAR (ROUND IN TWO DIMENSIONS)_CIRCULAR (ROUND IN TWO DIMENSIONS)_Seri_1
Segments: k p ˈɛː t i x
Comment: Glossed as 'circular, round'. Word class: intransitive verb. Basic forms: 3 sg. t=pˈɛːtix, 3 pl. t=pˈɛːtiɬ-k.

Polysemy: 'ground / loose soil / sand'. Word class: noun. Etymologically identical to 'earth' q.v. Secondary synonyms: ʔamt koːp 'sand', literally 'white earth' [ibid.]; ʔant kˈaːitik 'sand', literally 'soft earth' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 324].

Word class: irregular intransitive verb. "Occurs with an indirect quote, typically with reduced accent". This is the only verb used in the diagnostic context "X says/said that Y". Secondary synonyms: k=ɛː 'say / mean, signify' (intransitive verb, "Generally an addressee is not mentioned") [Moser & Marlett 2010: 472], k=i=ʔ 'put (soft thing, like clothing) / do (an action), make / say, pronounce, declare, talk about' (transitive verb, the direct object is the utterance or the addressee) [Moser & Marlett 2010: 487], k=iː 'say to, tell' (transitive verb, the direct object is the addressee, the utterance is indirectly presented as "thus") [Moser & Marlett 2010: 494-495], k=i=m 'say, tell' (transitive verb, does not allow an indirect object) [Moser & Marlett 2010: 517], kʷ=k=aːm 'say (something, to someone) / promise (something, to someone)' (transitive verb, requires a singular indirect object, referring to the addressee) [Moser & Marlett 2010: 273].

Polysemy: 'see / find / look at / recognize / have'. Word class: transitive verb. Basic forms: pf. 3 sg. i=t=ˈaʔo, impf. 3 sg. i=t=ˈaʔo-tim, pf. 3 pl. i=t=ˈaʔ-t, impf. 3 pl. i=t=ˈaʔ-toɬka. Cf. also the detransitivized verb k=okˈo=ʔo 'see', derived from k=ˈi=ʔo [Moser & Marlett 2010: 200].
Polysemy: 'seed / pit (of a fruit)'. Word class: possessed noun. Plural: ˈi=ʔi[x]k.

Polysemy: 'seated, sit / be (seated)'. Word class: intransitive verb. Basic forms: pf. 3 sg. t=iːx; impf. 3 sg. t=ˈiːkoɬ-im; pf. 3 pl. t=ˈaʔka; impf. 3 pl. t=ˈaʔaxka (human beings and animals), t=ˈoːa-ɬka (things).

Polysemy: 'skin of a person / skin or hide of an animal / epidermis or bark of a plant or tree / skin or peel of a fruit or vegetable / shell of an egg / shell of a mollusk / exoskeleton of an arthropod / exterior part of a bottle or can / casing or shell of a bullet / body of an automobile'. The general meaning of this word is defined in the dictionary as 'the integral part of something that encases it'. Word class: possessed noun. Plural: i=nˈaːax (i=nˈaːiɬ-k for shells of mollusks).
Word class: intransitive verb. Basic forms: pf. 3 sg. t=iːm; impf. 3 sg. t=ˈiːmam; 3 pl. t=ˈiːima.

Glossed as 'small, little, miniature'. Word class: intransitive verb. Basic forms: 3 sg. t=ˈisiɬ; 3 pl. t=ˈišiɬ, t=it, t=ˈiat. Antonym: k=ˈaːkox 'large, big' q.v. Secondary synonyms: ʔˈɛːkɛ 'young (especially animal) / small' (adjective, plural: ʔˈɛːk-to) [Moser & Marlett 2010: 371], koːɬ 'small' (adjective, archaic) [Moser & Marlett 2010: 223], šaːk 'small' (adjective, plural: šˈaːka-ɬk) "This word is found only in a few expressions. It does not have a predicative usage" [Moser & Marlett 2010: 609].

Segments: ʔ a m k ˈaː χ a t
Comment: Word class: noun. Plural: ʔamk=ˈaːata-ɬka. Cf. ʔamˈak 'fire' q.v., and k=ˈaːat 'be with smoke or steam' (intransitive verb) [Moser & Marlett 2010: 82].
Polysemy: 'be standing / be (standing)'. Word class: irregular intransitive verb. Basic forms: pf. 3 sg. t=ap; impf. 3 sg. t=ˈap-tim; pf. 3 pl. t=oiː, t=ˈoːyox, t=ˈoːyoɬ-kam; impf. 3 pl. t=ˈoːyoɬ-ka.

Polysemy: 'star / planet'. Word class: noun. Plural: ašɬ-k, ašɬ. Variant: ˈiːšox. "Some people use the variant ˈiːšox when talking about less notable stars in the sky". In 19th century word lists the word is attested as vasoh, bassojh, vashój, vassoglh [Marlett 2010: 25], with the phoneme w- or v-, completely lost in modern Seri. Secondary synonyms: ˈašox kˈanox 'star / sea star (general term) (Asteroidea)' [ibid.] (cf. k=ˈanox 'burn with a hissing sound'), ʔamˈak 'fire / lamp / star (archaic)' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 318].
Polysemy: 'rock, stone / hill / mountain'. Word class: noun. Plural: ʔˈasat-ox. Same word as 'mountain' q.v.

Polysemy: 'sun / sunshine, sunlight / day / clock / a venus clam similar to but larger than kamˈašxix (Megapitaria aurantiaca)'. Word class: noun. Secondary synonyms: ʔant kʷkˈiyoka 'sun' (archaic, literally 'that which buds out of earth', from k=ˈiyoš 'bud out') [Moser & Marlett 2010: 326], šiː ʔamˈiːmɛ kˈaːo 'sun' (archaic (San Esteban dialect), literally 'thing which travels in the sky') [Moser & Marlett 2010: 622].
Word class: irregular intransitive verb. Basic forms: pf. 3 sg. t=ˈakat, impf. 3 sg. t=ˈakat-im, pf. 3 pl. t=ˈakat-ax, impf. 3 pl. t=ˈakat-aɬka. "Conjugated as if the root began with a long vowel".
Word class: possessed noun. Plural: ˈiː=p-kox. Absolutive: ʔaː=p. Cf. ˈiː=pa-xʷ 'tail (of fish, bird or airplane), caudal fin' (plural: ˈiː=pa-o-ɬkam) [Moser & Marlett 2010: 407].
Glossed as 'that one'. Word class: demonstrative pronoun. Plural: taː [Moser & Marlett 2010: 560].
Glossed as 'this one'. Word class: demonstrative pronoun. Plural: ʔišˈaː.
Polysemy: 'thou / you (pl.)'. Word class: pronoun.
Word class: possessed noun. Plural: ˈi=paɬ-ox.
Word class: possessed noun. Plural: i=tˈaːsat-x.

Polysemy: 'plant / bush / tree / wood / stick / club / meter'. Word class: noun. Plural: ʔˈɛʔɛ-t. Secondary synonyms: ʔˈɛʔɛ ʔant iʔˈiti 'tree' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 374] (in the 2005 dictionary glossed as 'trunk of tree' [Moser & Marlett 2005: 373]) and ʔˈɛʔɛ ʔant kˈiti 'tree / large and well-established cactus' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 374] (cf. ʔant 'earth' q.v., and k=ˈiti 'connected (something "standing")' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 536]).
Word class: intransitive verb. Basic forms: 3 sg. t=oːkx, 3 pl. t=ˈoːkaɬ-kam. Cf. the interjection kˈaxkom 'two' (an archaic word, used only in counting) [Moser & Marlett 2010: 120].

Segments: k o n t ˈi k a
Comment: Polysemy: 'go away / go'. Word class: irregular intransitive verb. Basic forms: pf. 3 sg. ko=nt=ˈi=t=a, impf. 3 sg. ko=nt=ˈi=t=a-tim, pf. 3 pl. ko=nt=ˈi=t=a-t, impf. 3 pl. ko=nt=ˈi=t=a-toɬka. The verb has the same root as mˈo=k=a 'come' q.v. According to [Moser & Marlett 2010: 454], the prefix nt= "[o]ccurs with only a few verbs to indicate motion away". Another candidate is k=ˈata 'go / walk / move' (intransitive verb, basic forms: pf. 3 sg. t=ˈata, impf. 3 sg. t=ˈata-im, pf. 3 pl. t=aɬ, impf. 3 pl. t=ˈaɬa-oɬka). Examples in the dictionary show that ko=nt=ˈi=k=a is used when the goal of motion is explicitly mentioned, as in ʔant poɸˈiː ta, ʔɛ Sokˈaːi kontˈisa kˈaʔa 'Tomorrow morning I'm going to Punta Chueca' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 176], whereas k=ˈata occurs in phrases like ʔatˈɛː somkˈaːta ˈaʔa 'I won't go' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 53].

Glossed as 'hot'. Word class: intransitive verb. Basic forms: 3 sg. t=matx, 3 pl. t=mˈatšiɬ. Antonym: k=aːpɬ 'cold' q.v. Distinct from k=mˈɛkɛ 'warm, lukewarm' (intransitive verb, basic forms: pf. 3 sg. t=mˈɛkɛ, impf. 3 sg. t=mˈɛkɛ-tim, pf. 3 pl. t=mˈɛk-tox, impf. 3 pl. t=mˈɛkɛ-xam) [Moser & Marlett 2010: 186].

Polysemy: 'fresh water / superficial well'. Word class: possessed noun. 3 sg. possessor iː=. Plural: ʔˈa=a-xam. Secondary synonyms: ˈiːka ʔapˈam 'water', archaic, literally 'substance that is swallowed' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 588], ˈiːka kosˈiːin 'water', archaic, literally 'substance that lies down near' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 587].
Polysemy: 'I / we'. Word class: pronoun. In 19th century word lists the first person plural pronoun 'we' differs from the singular 'I' and is attested as oˈve, ove, ové [Marlett 2010: 32].
Polysemy: 'what (question) / who (question)'. Word class: pronoun. "The usage in the sense of 'who' is not common". Variant: ʔaš.
Word class: intransitive verb. Basic forms: pf. 3 sg. t=oːp; impf. 3 sg. t=ˈoːap-im; pf. 3 pl. t=ˈoːap-ox; impf. 3 pl. t=ˈoːap-oɬka.

Glossed as 'who, whom, whose (question)'. Word class: pronoun. Secondary synonyms: ʔaːʔkʷ 'who (question)' (archaic) [Moser & Marlett 2010: 302], aš 'what (question) / who (question)' ("The usage in the sense of 'who' is not common") [Moser & Marlett 2010: 51]. Cf. also ʔˈaki 'which, which one, who (question)' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 342].

Polysemy: 'woman / female / kangaroo rat (Dipodomys sp.) / an unidentified mollusk'. Word class: noun. Plural of 'woman': kmaxˈiːk; (archaic) kmaxˈɛaːxox. Secondary synonym: šiː kipnˈaːiɬ 'woman' (archaic, literally 'thing with skirt') [Moser & Marlett 2010: 631].

Segments: k m ˈa s o ɬ
Comment: Polysemy: 'yellow / blond (hair)'. Word class: intransitive verb. Basic forms: 3 sg. t=mˈasoɬ, 3 pl. t=masɬ.

Glossed as 'far away'. Word class: preposed adverb. Cf. ˈaːmo 'a bit far away, at an intermediate distance / for a long time' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 39] and koɬ 'very high up / distant (on the sea)' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 209].

Segments: k m ˈo t ɛ t
Comment: Polysemy: 'heavy / difficult'. Word class: intransitive verb. Basic forms: 3 sg. t=mˈotɛt, 3 pl. t=mˈotɛt-ax. Variant: k=mˈotit.

Segments: ʔ a n t ˈa χ ɬ
Comment: Word class: preposed adverb. Another candidate is iːk 'near' (preposed adverb) [Moser & Marlett 2010: 403].

Segments: ʔ a n t ˈi p
Comment: Word class: noun. Secondary synonyms: šiː ˈiːki ikˈaːi 'salt', archaic, San Esteban dialect [Moser & Marlett 2010: 627] (from ˈiːki kˈaːi 'sprinkle (e.g. salt)' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 62-63]); šiː ˈiːki ikˈoːʔit 'salt', archaic [Moser & Marlett 2010: 627] (from k=ˈoː=ʔit 'eat') [Moser & Marlett 2010: 218].

Glossed as 'small, little, miniature'. Word class: intransitive verb. Basic forms: 3 sg. t=ˈisiɬ; 3 pl. t=ˈišiɬ, t=it, t=ˈiat. Two words glossed as 'short' in the dictionary are not eligible: k=ˈoːxox 'bajito / short (in stature)' (intransitive verb) [Moser & Marlett 2010: 222] and pˈoːtsi 'chaparro, que dejó de crecer / short, stunted' (adjective, rarely used) - a loanword from Southern Uto-Aztecan languages [Moser & Marlett 2010: 468]. Note that neither of these two words is glossed as 'corto' in Spanish. We tentatively choose k=ˈisiɬ because this word is translated as 'corto / short' in the following two examples: ʔap kiʔ kasˈoːpoɬka kap itˈaːmaɬka kiʔ ʔoː insˈoːpɬox, ʔoː oː tit. 'Los cuernos de un venado bura con una punta en cada cuerno son muy gruesos y cortos. / The antlers of a spike horn mule deer are very thick and short' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 147] and ʔaktˈaːpa ʔyˈaːi kiʔ tˈisiɬ ma, iʔmˈaː š ˈiyat iʔyošˈam. 'Como el palo para recolectar fruta que hice es corto, puse otro en su punta (para alargarlo). / Since the pole that I made is short, I put another one on the end (to make it longer)' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 313].

Segments: ʃ iː χ k o k ˈa ʃ n i ʔ a n t kʷ k iː ʔ
Comment: Glossed as 'general term for biting snakes'. Literally: 'thing similar to rattlesnake' (k=o=kˈašni 'rattlesnake, especially western diamondback (Crotalus spp., especially C. atrox)' [ibid.], derived from k=kˈašni 'bite (snake) / pinch (crab)' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 172]). Cf. šiː koˈiːmax ʔant kʷkiːʔ 'general term for non-biting snakes', literally 'thing similar to whipsnake' (koˈiːmax 'coachwhip, whipsnake (Masticophis spp., including M. bilineatus, M. flagellum, M. slevini)') [Moser & Marlett 2010: 207].

ID: Seri_THIN (OF HAIR AND THREAD)_THIN (OF HAIR AND THREAD)_Seri_1
Segments: k χ ˈa t k a x
Comment: Word class: intransitive verb. Basic forms: 3 sg. t=ˈatkax, 3 pl. t=atɬk. The word is applied to animal skin [Moser & Marlett 2010: 244, 247], tree bark [Moser & Marlett 2010: 119] etc. In the first edition of the dictionary it is glossed as 'thin (like paper)' [Moser & Marlett 2005: 264].

ID: Seri_THIN (OF LEAF AND CLOTH)_THIN (OF LEAF AND CLOTH)_Seri_1
Comment: Glossed as 'thin, narrow'. Word class: intransitive verb. Basic forms: 3 sg. t=ˈoːsot, 3 pl. t=ˈoːsot-ox. For the meaning 'thin (1D)' cf. the compounds ˈɛːnim kˈoːsot 'wire / nail', literally 'thin metal' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 295] and kˈaːsoɬ ˈitak kˈoːsotox 'slender burro brush', literally 'kˈaːsoɬ with thin stem' [Moser & Marlett 2010: 80].

Polysemy: 'wind / breeze / north wind / air'. Word class: noun. In 19th century word lists the word is attested as âve, abb, avb̌ǐ (avü) [Marlett 2010: 26], with the phoneme -w- or -v-, completely lost in modern Seri.

Polysemy: 'earth, dirt, land / world, earth / place / year / weather'. Word class: noun. Same word as 'earth' q.v. The polysemy 'earth / year' reminds of two similar cases: šaːʔ 'sun / day' and ˈiːša 'moon / month'.
